dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this son of York; And all the clouds that loured upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried. Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths, Our bruised arms hung up for monuments, Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings, Our dreadful marches to delightful measures. Grim-visaged war hath smoothed his wrinkled front; And now, instead of mounting barbed steeds To fright the souls of fearful adversaries, He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber To the lascivious pleasing of a lute. But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks, Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass; I, that am rudely stamped, and want love's majesty To strut before a wanton ambling nymph; I, that am curtailed of this fair proportion, Cheated of feature by dissembling nature, Deformed, unfinished, sent before my time Into this breathing world scarce half made up, And that so lamely and unfashionable That dogs bark at me as I halt by them- Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace, Have no delight to pass away the time, Unless to spy my shadow in the sun, And descant on mine own deformity. And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover To entertain these fair well-spoken days, I am determined to prove a villain, And hate the idle pleasures of these days. Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous, By drunken prophecies, libels, and dreams, To set my brother Clarence and the King In deadly hate the one against the other; And if King Edward be as true and just As I am subtle, false, and treacherous, This day should Clarence closely be mewed up About a prophecy which says that "G" Of Edward's heirs the murderer shall be. Dive, thoughts, down to my soul. Here Clarence comes. Brother, good day. What means this armed guard That waits upon your Grace?

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: His Majesty, Tend'ring my person's safety, hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Upon what cause?

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Because my name is George.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours. He should, for that, commit your godfathers. O, belike his Majesty hath some intent That you should be new-christened in the Tower. But what's the matter, Clarence? May I know?

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Yea, Richard, when I know, for I protest As yet I do not. But, as I can learn, He hearkens after prophecies and dreams, And from the cross-row plucks the letter G, And says a wizard told him that by "G" His issue disinherited should be. And for my name of George begins with G, It follows in his thought that I am he. These, as I learn, and such like toys as these, Hath moved his Highness to commit me now.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Why, this it is when men are ruled by women. 'Tis not the King that sends you to the Tower; My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, 'tis she That tempers him to this extremity. Was it not she and that good man of worship, Antony Woodville, her brother there, That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower, From whence this present day he is delivered? We are not safe, Clarence; we are not safe.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: By heaven, I think there is no man secure But the Queen's kindred, and night-walking heralds That trudge betwixt the King and Mistress Shore. Heard you not what an humble suppliant Lord Hastings was to her for his delivery?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Humbly complaining to her deity Got my Lord Chamberlain his liberty. I'll tell you what: I think it is our way, If we will keep in favour with the King, To be her men and wear her livery. The jealous o'er-worn widow and herself, Since that our brother dubbed them gentlewomen, Are mighty gossips in our monarchy.

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: I beseech your Graces both to pardon me. His Majesty hath straitly given in charge That no man shall have private conference, Of what degree soever, with your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Even so; an please your worship, Brakenbury, You may partake of anything we say. We speak no treason, man. We say the King Is wise and virtuous, and his noble Queen Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous. We say that Shore's wife hath a pretty foot, A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue; And that the Queen's kindred are made gentlefolks. How say you, sir? Can you deny all this?

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: With this, my lord, myself have naught to do.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Naught to do with Mistress Shore? I tell thee, fellow, He that doth naught with her, excepting one, Were best to do it secretly alone.

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: What one, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Her husband, knave! Wouldst thou betray me?

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: I do beseech your Grace to pardon me, and withal Forbear your conference with the noble Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: We are the Queen's abjects and must obey. Brother, farewell. I will unto the King, And whatsoe'er you will employ me in, Were it to call King Edward's widow "sister," I will perform it to enfranchise you. Meantime, this deep disgrace in brotherhood Touches me deeper than you can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long. I will deliver or else lie for you. Meantime, have patience.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: I must perforce. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Go tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return. Simple, plain Clarence, I do love thee so That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven, If heaven will take the present at our hands. But who comes here? The new-delivered Hastings?

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Good time of day unto my gracious lord.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: As much unto my good Lord Chamberlain. Well are you welcome to the open air. How hath your lordship brooked imprisonment?

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must; But I shall live, my lord, to give them thanks That were the cause of my imprisonment.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: No doubt, no doubt; and so shall Clarence too, For they that were your enemies are his, And have prevailed as much on him as you.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: More pity that the eagles should be mewed, Whiles kites and buzzards prey at liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: What news abroad?

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: No news so bad abroad as this at home: The King is sickly, weak, and melancholy, And his physicians fear him mightily.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Now, by Saint John, that news is bad indeed. O, he hath kept an evil diet long, And overmuch consumed his royal person. 'Tis very grievous to be thought upon. Where is he, in his bed?

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: He is.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Go you before, and I will follow you. He cannot live, I hope, and must not die Till George be packed with post-horse up to heaven. I'll in to urge his hatred more to Clarence With lies well steeled with weighty arguments; And, if I fail not in my deep intent, Clarence hath not another day to live; Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy, And leave the world for me to bustle in. For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter. What though I killed her husband and her father? The readiest way to make the wench amends Is to become her husband and her father; The which will I, not all so much for love As for another secret close intent, By marrying her which I must reach unto. But yet I run before my horse to market. Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns. When they are gone, then must I count my gains.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Set down, set down your honourable load, If honour may be shrouded in a hearse, Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament Th' untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster. Poor key-cold figure of a holy king, Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster. Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood, Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost To hear the lamentations of poor Anne, Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughtered son, Stabbed by the selfsame hand that made these wounds. Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes. O, cursed be the hand that made these holes; Cursed the heart that had the heart to do it; Cursed the blood that let this blood from hence. More direful hap betide that hated wretch That makes us wretched by the death of thee Than I can wish to adders, spiders, toads, Or any creeping venomed thing that lives. If ever he have child, abortive be it, Prodigious, and untimely brought to light, Whose ugly and unnatural aspect May fright the hopeful mother at the view, And that be heir to his unhappiness. If ever he have wife, let her be made More miserable by the death of him Than I am made by my young lord and thee. Come now towards Chertsey with your holy load, Taken from Paul's to be interred there; And still, as you are weary of this weight, Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry's corse.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Stay, you that bear the corse, and set it down.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: What black magician conjures up this fiend To stop devoted charitable deeds?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Villains, set down the corse or, by Saint Paul, I'll make a corse of him that disobeys!

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: My lord, stand back, and let the coffin pass.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Unmannered dog, stand thou, when I command! Advance thy halberd higher than my breast, Or by Saint Paul I'll strike thee to my foot And spurn upon thee, beggar, for thy boldness.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: What, do you tremble? Are you all afraid? Alas, I blame you not, for you are mortal, And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil. Avaunt, thou dreadful minister of hell! Thou hadst but power over his mortal body; His soul thou canst not have; therefore begone.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Foul devil, for God's sake, hence, and trouble us not; For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell, Filled it with cursing cries and deep exclaims. If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds, Behold this pattern of thy butcheries. O, gentlemen, see, see dead Henry's wounds Open their congealed mouths and bleed afresh! Blush, blush, thou lump of foul deformity, For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blood From cold and empty veins where no blood dwells. Thy deeds, inhuman and unnatural, Provokes this deluge most unnatural. O God, which this blood mad'st, revenge his death! O earth, which this blood drink'st, revenge his death! Either heaven with lightning strike the murderer dead, Or earth gape open wide and eat him quick, As thou dost swallow up this good King's blood, Which his hell-governed arm hath butchered.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Lady, you know no rules of charity, Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Villain, thou know'st nor law of God nor man. No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: O wonderful, when devils tell the truth!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: More wonderful when angels are so angry. Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman, Of these supposed crimes to give me leave, By circumstance, but to acquit myself.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Vouchsafe, diffused infection of a man, Of these known evils but to give me leave, By circumstance, to accuse thy cursed self.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have Some patient leisure to excuse myself.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make No excuse current but to hang thyself.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: By such despair I should accuse myself.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: And by despairing shalt thou stand excused For doing worthy vengeance on thyself That didst unworthy slaughter upon others.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Say that I slew them not?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Then say they were not slain. But dead they are, and, devilish slave, by thee.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I did not kill your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Why then he is alive.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Nay, he is dead, and slain by Edward's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: In thy foul throat thou liest. Queen Margaret saw Thy murd'rous falchion smoking in his blood, The which thou once didst bend against her breast, But that thy brothers beat aside the point.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I was provoked by her sland'rous tongue, That laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind, That never dream'st on aught but butcheries. Didst thou not kill this King?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I grant ye.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Dost grant me, hedgehog? Then, God grant me too Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed. O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: The better for the King of Heaven that hath him.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Let him thank me that holp to send him thither, For he was fitter for that place than earth.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: And thou unfit for any place but hell.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Some dungeon.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Your bed-chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Ill rest betide the chamber where thou liest!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: So will it, madam, till I lie with you.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I know so. But, gentle Lady Anne, To leave this keen encounter of our wits, And fall something into a slower method: Is not the causer of the timeless deaths Of these Plantagenets, Henry and Edward, As blameful as the executioner?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Thou wast the cause and most accursed effect.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Your beauty was the cause of that effect: Your beauty, that did haunt me in my sleep To undertake the death of all the world, So I might live one hour in your sweet bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: If I thought that, I tell thee, homicide, These nails should rend that beauty from my cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: These eyes could not endure that beauty's wrack; You should not blemish it if I stood by. As all the world is cheered by the sun, So I by that; it is my day, my life.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Black night o'ershade thy day, and death thy life.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Curse not thyself, fair creature; thou art both.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: It is a quarrel most unnatural, To be revenged on him that loveth thee.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: It is a quarrel just and reasonable, To be revenged on him that killed my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: He that bereft thee, lady, of thy husband, Did it to help thee to a better husband.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: His better doth not breathe upon the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: He lives that loves thee better than he could.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Name him.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Plantagenet.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Why, that was he.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Here. Why dost thou spit at me?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Would it were mortal poison, for thy sake.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Never came poison from so sweet a place.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Never hung poison on a fouler toad. Out of my sight! Thou dost infect mine eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Would they were basilisks to strike thee dead!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I would they were, that I might die at once; For now they kill me with a living death. Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears, Shamed their aspects with store of childish drops. These eyes, which never shed remorseful tear, No, when my father York and Edward wept To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him; Nor when thy warlike father, like a child, Told the sad story of my father's death, And twenty times made pause to sob and weep, That all the standers-by had wet their cheeks Like trees bedashed with rain. In that sad time My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear; And what these sorrows could not thence exhale, Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping. I never sued to friend nor enemy; My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word; But now thy beauty is proposed my fee, My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak. Teach not thy lip such scorn; for it was made For kissing, lady, not for such contempt. If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive, Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword, Which if thou please to hide in this true breast And let the soul forth that adoreth thee, I lay it naked to the deadly stroke, And humbly beg the death upon my knee,  Nay, do not pause, for I did kill King Henry- But 'twas thy beauty that provoked me. Nay, now dispatch; 'twas I that stabbed young Edward- But 'twas thy heavenly face that set me on. Take up the sword again, or take up me.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Arise, dissembler. Though I wish thy death, I will not be thy executioner.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I have already.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: That was in thy rage. Speak it again, and even with the word, This hand, which for thy love did kill thy love, Shall for thy love kill a far truer love. To both their deaths shalt thou be accessary.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I would I knew thy heart.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: 'Tis figured in my tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I fear me both are false.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Then never was man true.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Well, well, put up your sword.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Say then my peace is made.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: That shalt thou know hereafter.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: But shall I live in hope?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: All men, I hope, live so.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: To take is not to give.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Look how my ring encompasseth thy finger; Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart; Wear both of them, for both of them are thine. And if thy poor devoted servant may But beg one favour at thy gracious hand, Thou dost confirm his happiness for ever.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: That it may please you leave these sad designs To him that hath most cause to be a mourner, And presently repair to Crosby Place; Where, after I have solemnly interred At Chertsey monastery this noble King, And wet his grave with my repentant tears, I will with all expedient duty see you. For divers unknown reasons, I beseech you, Grant me this boon.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: With all my heart, and much it joys me too To see you are become so penitent. Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Bid me farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: 'Tis more than you deserve; But since you teach me how to flatter you, Imagine I have said farewell already.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Sirs, take up the corse.

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: Towards Chertsey, noble lord?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: No, to White Friars; there attend my coming. Was ever woman in this humour wooed? Was ever woman in this humour won? I'll have her, but I will not keep her long. What, I that killed her husband and his father, To take her in her heart's extremest hate, With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes, The bleeding witness of her hatred by, Having God, her conscience, and these bars against me, And I no friends to back my suit at all, But the plain devil and dissembling looks? And yet to win her, all the world to nothing! Ha! Hath she forgot already that brave prince, Edward, her lord, whom I, some three months since, Stabbed in my angry mood at Tewksbury? A sweeter and a lovelier gentleman, Framed in the prodigality of nature, Young, valiant, wise, and, no doubt, right royal, The spacious world cannot again afford. And will she yet abase her eyes on me, That cropped the golden prime of this sweet prince, And made her widow to a woeful bed? On me, whose all not equals Edward's moiety? On me, that halt and am misshapen thus? My dukedom to a beggarly denier, I do mistake my person all this while! Upon my life, she finds, although I cannot, Myself to be a marvellous proper man. I'll be at charges for a looking-glass, And entertain a score or two of tailors To study fashions to adorn my body. Since I am crept in favour with myself, I will maintain it with some little cost. But first I'll turn yon fellow in his grave, And then return lamenting to my love. Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass, That I may see my shadow as I pass.

scenes.location: London. A Room in the Palace

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Have patience, madam. There's no doubt his Majesty Will soon recover his accustomed health.

dialogues.speaker: Grey
dialogues.line: In that you brook it ill, it makes him worse. Therefore, for God's sake, entertain good comfort, And cheer his Grace with quick and merry eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: If he were dead, what would betide on me?

dialogues.speaker: Grey
dialogues.line: No other harm but loss of such a lord.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: The loss of such a lord includes all harms.

dialogues.speaker: Grey
dialogues.line: The heavens have blessed you with a goodly son To be your comforter when he is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Ah, he is young, and his minority Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester, A man that loves not me, nor none of you.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Is it concluded he shall be Protector?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: It is determined, not concluded yet; But so it must be, if the King miscarry.

dialogues.speaker: Grey
dialogues.line: Here come the Lords of Buckingham and Derby.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Good time of day unto your royal Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: God make your Majesty joyful as you have been.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: The Countess Richmond, good my Lord of Derby, To your good prayer will scarcely say amen. Yet, Derby, notwithstanding she's your wife, And loves not me, be you, good lord, assured I hate not you for her proud arrogance.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: I do beseech you, either not believe The envious slanders of her false accusers, Or if she be accused on true report, Bear with her weakness, which I think proceeds From wayward sickness, and no grounded malice.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Saw you the King today, my Lord of Derby?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: But now the Duke of Buckingham and I Are come from visiting his Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: What likelihood of his amendment, lords?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Madam, good hope; his Grace speaks cheerfully.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: God grant him health! Did you confer with him?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Ay, madam; he desires to make atonement Between the Duke of Gloucester and your brothers, And between them and my Lord Chamberlain; And sent to warn them to his royal presence.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Would all were well-but that will never be. I fear our happiness is at the height.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: They do me wrong, and I will not endure it! Who is it that complains unto the King That I, forsooth, am stern and love them not? By holy Paul, they love his Grace but lightly That fill his ears with such dissentious rumours. Because I cannot flatter and look fair, Smile in men's faces, smooth, deceive, and cog, Duck with French nods and apish courtesy, I must be held a rancorous enemy. Cannot a plain man live and think no harm, But thus his simple truth must be abused With silken, sly, insinuating Jacks?

dialogues.speaker: Grey
dialogues.line: To who in all this presence speaks your Grace?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace. When have I injured thee? When done thee wrong? Or thee? Or thee? Or any of your faction? A plague upon you all! His royal Grace, Whom God preserve better than you would wish, Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing while But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter. The King, on his own royal disposition, And not provoked by any suitor else, Aiming, belike, at your interior hatred That in your outward action shows itself Against my children, brothers, and myself, Makes him to send, that he may learn the ground Of your ill will, and thereby to remove it.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I cannot tell. The world is grown so bad That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch. Since every Jack became a gentleman, There's many a gentle person made a Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Come, come, we know your meaning, brother Gloucester. You envy my advancement, and my friends'. God grant we never may have need of you.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Meantime, God grants that we have need of you. Our brother is imprisoned by your means, Myself disgraced, and the nobility Held in contempt, while great promotions Are daily given to ennoble those That scarce some two days since were worth a noble.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: By Him that raised me to this careful height From that contented hap which I enjoyed, I never did incense his Majesty Against the Duke of Clarence, but have been An earnest advocate to plead for him. My lord, you do me shameful injury Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: You may deny that you were not the mean Of my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: She may, my lord; for-

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: She may, Lord Rivers; why, who knows not so? She may do more, sir, than denying that. She may help you to many fair preferments, And then deny her aiding hand therein, And lay those honours on your high desert. What may she not? She may, ay, marry, may she-

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: What, marry, may she?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: What, marry, may she? Marry with a king, A bachelor, and a handsome stripling too. Iwis your grandam had a worser match.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: My lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs. By heaven, I will acquaint his Majesty Of those gross taunts that oft I have endured. I had rather be a country servant-maid Than a great queen with this condition, To be so baited, scorned, and stormed at. Small joy have I in being England's queen.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: And lessened be that small, God, I beseech Him! Thy honour, state, and seat, is due to me.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: What, threat you me with telling of the King? Tell him, and spare not. Look what I have said I will avouch 't in presence of the King; I dare adventure to be sent to th' Tower. 'Tis time to speak. My pains are quite forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Out, devil! I do remember them too well: Thou killed'st my husband Henry in the Tower, And Edward, my poor son, at Tewksbury.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Ere you were queen, ay, or your husband king, I was a pack-horse in his great affairs; A weeder-out of his proud adversaries, A liberal rewarder of his friends. To royalize his blood, I spilt mine own.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Ay, and much better blood than his or thine.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: In all which time, you and your husband Grey Were factious for the house of Lancaster. And, Rivers, so were you. Was not your husband In Margaret's battle at Saint Albans slain? Let me put in your minds, if you forget, What you have been ere this, and what you are; Withal, what I have been, and what I am.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: A murd'rous villain, and so still thou art.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Poor Clarence did forsake his father Warwick, Ay, and forswore himself-which Jesu pardon!-

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Which God revenge!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: To fight on Edward's party for the crown; And for his meed, poor lord, he is mewed up. I would to God my heart were flint, like Edward's, Or Edward's soft and pitiful, like mine. I am too childish-foolish for this world.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Hie thee to hell for shame, and leave this world, Thou cacodemon! There thy kingdom is.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: My lord of Gloucester, in those busy days Which here you urge to prove us enemies, We followed then our lord, our sovereign king. So should we you, if you should be our king.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: If I should be! I had rather be a pedler. Far be it from my heart, the thought thereof.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: As little joy, my lord, as you suppose You should enjoy, were you this country's king, As little joy you may suppose in me That I enjoy, being the Queen thereof.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: As little joy enjoys the Queen thereof, For I am she, and altogether joyless. I can no longer hold me patient. Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out In sharing that which you have pilled from me! Which of you trembles not that looks on me? If not, that I am Queen, you bow like subjects, Yet that, by you deposed, you quake like rebels. Ah, gentle villain, do not turn away.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Foul wrinkled witch, what mak'st thou in my sight?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: But repetition of what thou hast marred. That will I make before I let thee go.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Wert thou not banished on pain of death?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: I was, but I do find more pain in banishment Than death can yield me here by my abode. A husband and a son thou ow'st to me; And thou a kingdom; all of you, allegiance. This sorrow that I have by right is yours; And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: The curse my noble father laid on thee When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper, And with thy scorns drew'st rivers from his eyes, And then to dry them, gav'st the Duke a clout Steeped in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland- His curses then, from bitterness of soul Denounced against thee, are all fall'n upon thee, And God, not we, hath plagued thy bloody deed.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: So just is God, to right the innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: O, 'twas the foulest deed to slay that babe, And the most merciless that e'er was heard of.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.

dialogues.speaker: Dorset
dialogues.line: No man but prophesied revenge for it.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: What, were you snarling all before I came, Ready to catch each other by the throat, And turn you all your hatred now on me? Did York's dread curse prevail so much with heaven That Henry's death, my lovely Edward's death, Their kingdom's loss, my woeful banishment, Should all but answer for that peevish brat? Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven? Why then, give way, dull clouds, to my quick curses! Though not by war, by surfeit die your King, As ours by murder, to make him a king. Edward thy son, that now is Prince of Wales, For Edward our son, that was Prince of Wales, Die in his youth by like untimely violence. Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen, Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self. Long mayst thou live to wail thy children's death, And see another, as I see thee now, Decked in thy rights, as thou art stalled in mine; Long die thy happy days before thy death, And, after many lengthened hours of grief, Die neither mother, wife, nor England's Queen. Rivers and Dorset, you were standers-by, And so wast thou, Lord Hastings, when my son Was stabbed with bloody daggers. God, I pray Him, That none of you may live his natural age, But by some unlooked accident cut off.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Have done thy charm, thou hateful withered hag.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: And leave out thee? Stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me. If heaven have any grievous plague in store Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee, O, let them keep it till thy sins be ripe, And then hurl down their indignation On thee, the troubler of the poor world's peace. The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul; Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou liv'st, And take deep traitors for thy dearest friends; No sleep close up that deadly eye of thine, Unless it be while some tormenting dream Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils. Thou elvish-marked, abortive, rooting hog, Thou that wast sealed in thy nativity The slave of nature and the son of hell; Thou slander of thy heavy mother's womb, Thou loathed issue of thy father's loins, Thou rag of honour, thou detested-

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Richard!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Ha?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: I call thee not.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I cry thee mercy then, for I did think That thou hadst called me all these bitter names.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Why, so I did, but looked for no reply. O, let me make the period to my curse!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: 'Tis done by me, and ends in "Margaret".

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune, Why strew'st thou sugar on that bottled spider, Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about? Fool, fool; thou whet'st a knife to kill thyself. The day will come that thou shalt wish for me To help thee curse this poisonous bunch-backed toad.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse, Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Foul shame upon you, you have all moved mine.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: To serve me well, you all should do me duty: Teach me to be your queen, and you my subjects. O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!

dialogues.speaker: Dorset
dialogues.line: Dispute not with her; she is lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Peace, Master Marquess, you are malapert. Your fire-new stamp of honour is scarce current. O, that your young nobility could judge What 'twere to lose it and be miserable! They that stand high have many blasts to shake them, And if they fall they dash themselves to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Good counsel, marry. Learn it, learn it, Marquess.

dialogues.speaker: Dorset
dialogues.line: It touches you, my lord, as much as me.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Ay, and much more; but I was born so high. Our aery buildeth in the cedar's top, And dallies with the wind, and scorns the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: And turns the sun to shade, alas, alas! Witness my son, now in the shade of death, Whose bright out-shining beams thy cloudy wrath Hath in eternal darkness folded up. Your aery buildeth in our aery's nest. O God, that seest it, do not suffer it! As it is won with blood, lost be it so.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Peace, peace, for shame, if not for charity.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Urge neither charity nor shame to me. Uncharitably with me have you dealt, And shamefully my hopes by you are butchered. My charity is outrage, life my shame, And in that shame still live my sorrow's rage.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Have done, have done.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: O princely Buckingham, I'll kiss thy hand In sign of league and amity with thee. Now fair befall thee and thy noble house! Thy garments are not spotted with our blood, Nor thou within the compass of my curse.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Nor no one here, for curses never pass The lips of those that breathe them in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: I will not think but they ascend the sky, And there awake God's gentle sleeping peace. O Buckingham, take heed of yonder dog! Look when he fawns, he bites; and when he bites, His venom tooth will rankle to the death. Have not to do with him; beware of him; Sin, death, and hell have set their marks on him, And all their ministers attend on him.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: What doth she say, my lord of Buckingham?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel, And soothe the devil that I warn thee from? O, but remember this another day, When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow, And say, poor Margaret was a prophetess. Live each of you the subjects to his hate, And he to yours, and all of you to God's!

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: My hair doth stand on end to hear her curses.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: And so doth mine. I muse why she's at liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I cannot blame her. By God's holy mother, She hath had too much wrong; and I repent My part thereof that I have done to her.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: I never did her any, to my knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Yet you have all the vantage of her wrong. I was too hot to do somebody good That is too cold in thinking of it now. Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid; He is franked up to fatting for his pains. God pardon them that are the cause thereof.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion, To pray for them that have done scathe to us.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: So do I ever-(_Speaks to himself_) being well advised; For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: Madam, his Majesty doth call for you, And for your Grace, and you, my gracious lords.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Catesby, I come. Lords, will you go with me?

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: We wait upon your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl. The secret mischiefs that I set abroach I lay unto the grievous charge of others. Clarence, whom I indeed have cast in darkness, I do beweep to many simple gulls, Namely, to Derby, Hastings, Buckingham; And tell them 'tis the Queen and her allies That stir the King against the Duke my brother. Now they believe it, and withal whet me To be revenged on Rivers, Dorset, Grey. But then I sigh, and, with a piece of Scripture, Tell them that God bids us do good for evil; And thus I clothe my naked villany With odd old ends stol'n forth of Holy Writ, And seem a saint when most I play the devil. But soft, here come my executioners. How now, my hardy, stout, resolved mates; Are you now going to dispatch this thing?

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: We are, my lord, and come to have the warrant, That we may be admitted where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Well thought upon; I have it here about me. When you have done, repair to Crosby Place. But, sirs, be sudden in the execution, Withal obdurate, do not hear him plead; For Clarence is well-spoken, and perhaps May move your hearts to pity, if you mark him.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Tut, tut, my lord, we will not stand to prate. Talkers are no good doers. Be assured We go to use our hands, and not our tongues.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Your eyes drop millstones when fools' eyes fall tears. I like you, lads. About your business straight. Go, go, dispatch.

dialogues.speaker: Both Murderers
dialogues.line: We will, my noble lord.

scenes.location: London. A Room in the Tower

dialogues.speaker: Keeper
dialogues.line: Why looks your Grace so heavily today?

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: O, I have passed a miserable night, So full of fearful dreams, of ugly sights, That, as I am a Christian faithful man, I would not spend another such a night Though 'twere to buy a world of happy days, So full of dismal terror was the time!

dialogues.speaker: Keeper
dialogues.line: What was your dream, my lord? I pray you tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower, And was embarked to cross to Burgundy; And in my company my brother Gloucester, Who from my cabin tempted me to walk Upon the hatches. Thence we looked toward England, And cited up a thousand heavy times, During the wars of York and Lancaster, That had befall'n us. As we paced along Upon the giddy footing of the hatches, Methought that Gloucester stumbled, and in falling, Struck me, that thought to stay him, overboard Into the tumbling billows of the main. O Lord, methought what pain it was to drown, What dreadful noise of waters in my ears; What sights of ugly death within my eyes. Methoughts I saw a thousand fearful wracks; A thousand men that fishes gnawed upon; Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl, Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels, All scattered in the bottom of the sea. Some lay in dead men's skulls, and in the holes Where eyes did once inhabit there were crept- As 'twere in scorn of eyes-reflecting gems, That wooed the slimy bottom of the deep, And mocked the dead bones that lay scattered by.

dialogues.speaker: Keeper
dialogues.line: Had you such leisure in the time of death To gaze upon these secrets of the deep?

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Methought I had; and often did I strive To yield the ghost, but still the envious flood Stopped in my soul, and would not let it forth To find the empty, vast, and wand'ring air, But smothered it within my panting bulk, Who almost burst to belch it in the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Keeper
dialogues.line: Awaked you not in this sore agony?

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: No, no, my dream was lengthened after life. O, then began the tempest to my soul. I passed, methought, the melancholy flood, With that sour ferryman which poets write of, Unto the kingdom of perpetual night. The first that there did greet my stranger-soul Was my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick, Who spake aloud, "What scourge for perjury Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?" And so he vanished. Then came wand'ring by A shadow like an angel, with bright hair Dabbled in blood; and he shrieked out aloud "Clarence is come-false, fleeting, perjured Clarence, That stabbed me in the field by Tewksbury! Seize on him, Furies! Take him unto torment!" With that, methoughts, a legion of foul fiends Environed me, and howled in mine ears Such hideous cries that with the very noise I trembling waked, and for a season after Could not believe but that I was in hell, Such terrible impression made my dream.

dialogues.speaker: Keeper
dialogues.line: No marvel, lord, though it affrighted you; I am afraid, methinks, to hear you tell it.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Ah, Keeper, Keeper, I have done these things, That now give evidence against my soul, For Edward's sake, and see how he requites me. O God, if my deep prayers cannot appease Thee, But Thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds, Yet execute Thy wrath in me alone; O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children! Keeper, I prithee sit by me awhile. My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Keeper
dialogues.line: I will, my lord; God give your Grace good rest.

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours, Makes the night morning, and the noontide night. Princes have but their titles for their glories, An outward honour for an inward toil; And, for unfelt imaginations, They often feel a world of restless cares, So that between their titles and low name, There's nothing differs but the outward fame.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Ho, who's here?

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: What wouldst thou, fellow? And how cam'st thou hither?

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: What, so brief?

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: 'Tis better, sir, than to be tedious. Let him see our commission, and talk no more.

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: I am in this commanded to deliver The noble Duke of Clarence to your hands. I will not reason what is meant hereby, Because I will be guiltless of the meaning. There lies the Duke asleep, and there the keys. I'll to the King and signify to him That thus I have resigned to you my charge.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: You may, sir; 'tis a point of wisdom. Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: What, shall I stab him as he sleeps?

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: No. He'll say 'twas done cowardly, when he wakes.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgement Day.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Why, then he'll say we stabbed him sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: The urging of that word "judgement" hath bred a kind of remorse in me.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: What, art thou afraid?

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Not to kill him, having a warrant, but to be damned for killing him, from the which no warrant can defend me.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: I thought thou hadst been resolute.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: So I am-to let him live.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: I'll back to the Duke of Gloucester and tell him so.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Nay, I prithee stay a little. I hope this passionate humour will change. It was wont to hold me but while one tells twenty.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: How dost thou feel thyself now?

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Remember our reward, when the deed's done.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Zounds, he dies! I had forgot the reward.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Where's thy conscience now?

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: O, in the Duke of Gloucester's purse.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: So, when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: 'Tis no matter; let it go. There's few or none will entertain it.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: What if it come to thee again?

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: I'll not meddle with it; it makes a man coward. A man cannot steal but it accuseth him; a man cannot swear but it checks him; a man cannot lie with his neighbour's wife but it detects him. 'Tis a blushing shamefaced spirit that mutinies in a man's bosom. It fills a man full of obstacles. It made me once restore a purse of gold that by chance I found. It beggars any man that keeps it. It is turned out of towns and cities for a dangerous thing; and every man that means to live well endeavours to trust to himself and live without it.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Zounds, 'tis even now at my elbow, persuading me not to kill the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Take the devil in thy mind, and believe him not. He would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: I am strong-framed; he cannot prevail with me.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Spoke like a tall man that respects thy reputation. Come, shall we fall to work?

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Take him on the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then throw him in the malmsey-butt in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: O excellent device-and make a sop of him.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Soft, he wakes.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Strike!

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: No, we'll reason with him.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Where art thou, keeper? Give me a cup of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: In God's name, what art thou?

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: A man, as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: But not as I am, royal.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Nor you as we are, loyal.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: My voice is now the King's, my looks mine own.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak! Your eyes do menace me; why look you pale? Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come?

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: To, to, to-

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: To murder me?

dialogues.speaker: Both Murderers
dialogues.line: Ay, ay.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so, And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it. Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Offended us you have not, but the King.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: I shall be reconciled to him again.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Never, my lord; therefore prepare to die.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Are you drawn forth among a world of men To slay the innocent? What is my offence? Where is the evidence that doth accuse me? What lawful quest have given their verdict up Unto the frowning judge? Or who pronounced The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death? Before I be convict by course of law, To threaten me with death is most unlawful. I charge you, as you hope to have redemption, By Christ's dear blood shed for our grievous sins, That you depart, and lay no hands on me. The deed you undertake is damnable.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: What we will do, we do upon command.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: And he that hath commanded is our King.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Erroneous vassals! The great King of kings Hath in the table of his law commanded That thou shalt do no murder. Will you then Spurn at His edict and fulfil a man's? Take heed, for He holds vengeance in His hand To hurl upon their heads that break His law.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: And that same vengeance doth He hurl on thee For false forswearing, and for murder too. Thou didst receive the sacrament to fight In quarrel of the house of Lancaster.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: And like a traitor to the name of God Didst break that vow, and with thy treacherous blade Unrippedst the bowels of thy sovereign's son.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Whom thou wast sworn to cherish and defend.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: How canst thou urge God's dreadful law to us, When thou hast broke it in such dear degree?

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Alas, for whose sake did I that ill deed? For Edward, for my brother, for his sake. He sends you not to murder me for this, For in that sin he is as deep as I. If God will be avenged for the deed, O, know you yet He doth it publicly; Take not the quarrel from His powerful arm; He needs no indirect or lawless course To cut off those that have offended Him.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Who made thee then a bloody minister When gallant-springing, brave Plantagenet, That princely novice, was struck dead by thee?

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: My brother's love, the devil, and my rage.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Thy brother's love, our duty, and thy faults, Provoke us hither now to slaughter thee.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: If you do love my brother, hate not me. I am his brother, and I love him well. If you are hired for meed, go back again, And I will send you to my brother Gloucester, Who shall reward you better for my life Than Edward will for tidings of my death.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: You are deceived. Your brother Gloucester hates you.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: O no, he loves me, and he holds me dear. Go you to him from me.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Ay, so we will.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Tell him when that our princely father York Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm, And charged us from his soul to love each other, He little thought of this divided friendship. Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Ay, millstones, as he lessoned us to weep.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: O, do not slander him, for he is kind.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Right, as snow in harvest. Come, you deceive yourself. 'Tis he that sends us to destroy you here.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: It cannot be, for he bewept my fortune, And hugged me in his arms, and swore with sobs That he would labour my delivery.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Why, so he doth, when he delivers you From this earth's thraldom to the joys of heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Have you that holy feeling in your souls To counsel me to make my peace with God, And are you yet to your own souls so blind That you will war with God by murd'ring me? O sirs, consider: they that set you on To do this deed will hate you for the deed.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: What shall we do?

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Relent, and save your souls.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Relent? No, 'tis cowardly and womanish.

dialogues.speaker: Clarence
dialogues.line: Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish. Which of you-if you were a prince's son, Being pent from liberty, as I am now- If two such murderers as yourselves came to you, Would not entreat for life? Ay, you would beg, Were you in my distress. My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks. O, if thine eye be not a flatterer, Come thou on my side, and entreat for me; A begging prince what beggar pities not?

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: Look behind you, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: Take that, and that!  If all this will not do, I'll drown you in the malmsey-butt within.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: A bloody deed, and desperately dispatched. How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my hands Of this most grievous murder.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: How now? What mean'st thou that thou help'st me not? By heavens, the Duke shall know how slack you have been.

dialogues.speaker: Second Murderer
dialogues.line: I would he knew that I had saved his brother. Take thou the fee, and tell him what I say, For I repent me that the Duke is slain.

dialogues.speaker: First Murderer
dialogues.line: So do not I. Go, coward as thou art. Well, I'll go hide the body in some hole Till that the Duke give order for his burial. And when I have my meed, I will away, For this will out, and then I must not stay.

scenes.location: London. A Room in the palace

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Why, so. Now have I done a good day's work. You peers, continue this united league. I every day expect an embassage From my Redeemer, to redeem me hence; And more at peace my soul shall part to heaven Since I have made my friends at peace on earth. Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand; Dissemble not your hatred. Swear your love.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: By heaven, my soul is purged from grudging hate, And with my hand I seal my true heart's love.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: So thrive I, as I truly swear the like.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Take heed you dally not before your King, Lest He that is the supreme King of kings Confound your hidden falsehood, and award Either of you to be the other's end.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: So prosper I, as I swear perfect love.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: And I, as I love Hastings with my heart.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Madam, yourself is not exempt from this; Nor you, son Dorset; Buckingham, nor you. You have been factious one against the other. Wife, love Lord Hastings, let him kiss your hand, And what you do, do it unfeignedly.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: There, Hastings, I will never more remember Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Dorset, embrace him; Hastings, love lord Marquess.

dialogues.speaker: Dorset
dialogues.line: This interchange of love, I here protest, Upon my part shall be inviolable.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: And so swear I.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wife's allies, And make me happy in your unity.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate Upon your Grace, but with all duteous love Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me With hate in those where I expect most love. When I have most need to employ a friend, And most assured that he is a friend, Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile Be he unto me: this do I beg of God, When I am cold in love to you or yours.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham, Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart. There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here, To make the blessed period of this peace.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: And in good time, Here comes Sir Ratcliffe and the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Good morrow to my sovereign King and Queen; And, princely peers, a happy time of day.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Happy indeed, as we have spent the day. Gloucester, we have done deeds of charity, Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate, Between these swelling wrong-incensed peers.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: A blessed labour, my most sovereign lord, Among this princely heap, if any here By false intelligence or wrong surmise Hold me a foe, If I unwittingly, or in my rage, Have aught committed that is hardly borne By any in this presence, I desire To reconcile me to his friendly peace. 'Tis death to me to be at enmity; I hate it, and desire all good men's love. First, madam, I entreat true peace of you, Which I will purchase with my duteous service; Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham, If ever any grudge were lodged between us; Of you and you, Lord Rivers and of Dorset, That all without desert have frowned on me; Of you, Lord Woodville and Lord Scales;-of you, Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen; indeed, of all. I do not know that Englishman alive With whom my soul is any jot at odds More than the infant that is born tonight. I thank my God for my humility.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter. I would to God all strifes were well compounded. My sovereign lord, I do beseech your Highness To take our brother Clarence to your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Why, madam, have I offered love for this, To be so flouted in this royal presence? Who knows not that the gentle Duke is dead? You do him injury to scorn his corse.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Who knows not he is dead! Who knows he is?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: All-seeing heaven, what a world is this!

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?

dialogues.speaker: Dorset
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord, and no man in the presence But his red colour hath forsook his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Is Clarence dead? The order was reversed.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: But he, poor man, by your first order died, And that a winged Mercury did bear; Some tardy cripple bore the countermand, That came too lag to see him buried. God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood, Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, And yet go current from suspicion!

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: A boon, my sovereign, for my service done!

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: I prithee, peace. My soul is full of sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: I will not rise unless your Highness hear me.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Then say at once what is it thou requests.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant's life Who slew today a riotous gentleman Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolk.

dialogues.speaker: King Edward
dialogues.line: Have I a tongue to doom my brother's death, And shall that tongue give pardon to a slave? My brother killed no man; his fault was thought, And yet his punishment was bitter death. Who sued to me for him? Who, in my wrath, Kneeled at my feet, and bid me be advised? Who spoke of brotherhood? Who spoke of love? Who told me how the poor soul did forsake The mighty Warwick, and did fight for me? Who told me, in the field at Tewksbury, When Oxford had me down, he rescued me, And said, "Dear brother, live, and be a king"? Who told me, when we both lay in the field Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me Even in his garments, and did give himself, All thin and naked, to the numb-cold night? All this from my remembrance brutish wrath Sinfully plucked, and not a man of you Had so much grace to put it in my mind. But when your carters or your waiting vassals Have done a drunken slaughter, and defaced The precious image of our dear Redeemer, You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon, And I, unjustly too, must grant it you. But for my brother not a man would speak, Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself For him, poor soul. The proudest of you all Have been beholding to him in his life, Yet none of you would once beg for his life. O God, I fear Thy justice will take hold On me, and you, and mine and yours for this! Come, Hastings, help me to my closet. Ah, poor Clarence!

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: This is the fruit of rashness. Marked you not How that the guilty kindred of the Queen Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence' death? O, they did urge it still unto the King. God will revenge it. Come, lords, will you go To comfort Edward with our company?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: We wait upon your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: Good grandam, tell us, is our father dead?

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: No, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Girl
dialogues.line: Why do you weep so oft, and beat your breast, And cry "O Clarence, my unhappy son"?

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: Why do you look on us, and shake your head, And call us orphans, wretches, castaways, If that our noble father were alive?

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: My pretty cousins, you mistake me both. I do lament the sickness of the King, As loath to lose him, not your father's death. It were lost sorrow to wail one that's lost.

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: Then you conclude, my grandam, he is dead. The King mine uncle is to blame for it. God will revenge it, whom I will importune With earnest prayers all to that effect.

dialogues.speaker: Girl
dialogues.line: And so will I.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Peace, children, peace. The King doth love you well. Incapable and shallow innocents, You cannot guess who caused your father's death.

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: Grandam, we can, for my good uncle Gloucester Told me, the King, provoked to it by the Queen, Devised impeachments to imprison him; And when my uncle told me so, he wept, And pitied me, and kindly kissed my cheek; Bade me rely on him as on my father, And he would love me dearly as his child.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Ah, that deceit should steal such gentle shape, And with a virtuous visard hide deep vice! He is my son, ay, and therein my shame; Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Ay, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: I cannot think it. Hark, what noise is this? after her.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Ah, who shall hinder me to wail and weep, To chide my fortune, and torment myself? I'll join with black despair against my soul And to myself become an enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: What means this scene of rude impatience?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: To make an act of tragic violence. Edward, my lord, thy son, our King, is dead. Why grow the branches when the root is gone? Why wither not the leaves that want their sap? If you will live, lament; if die, be brief, That our swift-winged souls may catch the King's Or, like obedient subjects, follow him To his new kingdom of ne'er-changing night.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow As I had title in thy noble husband. I have bewept a worthy husband's death, And lived by looking on his images; But now two mirrors of his princely semblance Are cracked in pieces by malignant death, And I, for comfort, have but one false glass, That grieves me when I see my shame in him. Thou art a widow, yet thou art a mother, And hast the comfort of thy children left; But death hath snatched my husband from mine arms And plucked two crutches from my feeble hands, Clarence and Edward. O, what cause have I, Thine being but a moiety of my moan, To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries.

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: Ah, aunt, you wept not for our father's death. How can we aid you with our kindred tears?

dialogues.speaker: Girl
dialogues.line: Our fatherless distress was left unmoaned. Your widow-dolour likewise be unwept!

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Give me no help in lamentation. I am not barren to bring forth complaints. All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes, That I, being governed by the watery moon, May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world. Ah, for my husband, for my dear Lord Edward!

dialogues.speaker: Children
dialogues.line: Ah for our father, for our dear Lord Clarence!

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: What stay had I but Edward? And he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Children
dialogues.line: What stay had we but Clarence? And he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: What stays had I but they? And they are gone.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Was never widow had so dear a loss.

dialogues.speaker: Children
dialogues.line: Were never orphans had so dear a loss.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Was never mother had so dear a loss. Alas, I am the mother of these griefs. Their woes are parcelled, mine is general. She for an Edward weeps, and so do I; I for a Clarence weep, so doth not she; These babes for Clarence weep, and so do I; I for an Edward weep, so do not they. Alas, you three, on me, threefold distressed, Pour all your tears. I am your sorrow's nurse, And I will pamper it with lamentation.

dialogues.speaker: Dorset
dialogues.line: Comfort, dear mother. God is much displeased That you take with unthankfulness His doing. In common worldly things 'tis called ungrateful With dull unwillingness to repay a debt Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent; Much more to be thus opposite with heaven, For it requires the royal debt it lent you.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother, Of the young prince your son. Send straight for him; Let him be crowned; in him your comfort lives. Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward's grave, And plant your joys in living Edward's throne. Ratcliffe.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Sister, have comfort. All of us have cause To wail the dimming of our shining star, But none can help our harms by wailing them. Madam my mother, I do cry you mercy; I did not see your Grace. Humbly on my knee I crave your blessing.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast, Love, charity, obedience, and true duty.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Amen.  And make me die a good old man! That is the butt end of a mother's blessing; I marvel that her Grace did leave it out.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers That bear this heavy mutual load of moan, Now cheer each other in each other's love. Though we have spent our harvest of this king, We are to reap the harvest of his son. The broken rancour of your high-swoll'n hates, But lately splintered, knit, and joined together, Must gently be preserved, cherished, and kept. Me seemeth good that with some little train, Forthwith from Ludlow the young Prince be fet Hither to London, to be crowned our King.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Why with some little train, my Lord of Buckingham?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Marry, my lord, lest by a multitude The new-healed wound of malice should break out, Which would be so much the more dangerous By how much the estate is green and yet ungoverned. Where every horse bears his commanding rein And may direct his course as please himself, As well the fear of harm as harm apparent, In my opinion, ought to be prevented.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I hope the King made peace with all of us; And the compact is firm and true in me.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: And so in me, and so, I think, in all. Yet since it is but green, it should be put To no apparent likelihood of breach, Which haply by much company might be urged. Therefore I say with noble Buckingham That it is meet so few should fetch the Prince.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: And so say I.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Then be it so, and go we to determine Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow. Madam, and you, my sister, will you go To give your censures in this business?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince, For God's sake, let not us two stay at home. For by the way I'll sort occasion, As index to the story we late talked of, To part the Queen's proud kindred from the Prince.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: My other self, my counsel's consistory, My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin, I, as a child, will go by thy direction. Toward Ludlow then, for we'll not stay behind.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Good morrow, neighbour, whither away so fast?

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: I promise you, I scarcely know myself. Hear you the news abroad?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Yes, that the King is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Ill news, by'r Lady; seldom comes the better. I fear, I fear 'twill prove a giddy world.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Neighbours, God speed.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Give you good morrow, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Doth the news hold of good King Edward's death?

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, it is too true, God help the while.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: No, no; by God's good grace, his son shall reign.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Woe to that land that's governed by a child.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: In him there is a hope of government, Which, in his nonage, council under him, And, in his full and ripened years, himself, No doubt shall then, and till then, govern well.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: So stood the state when Henry the Sixth Was crowned in Paris but at nine months old.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot. For then this land was famously enriched With politic grave counsel; then the King Had virtuous uncles to protect his Grace.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Why, so hath this, both by his father and mother.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Better it were they all came by his father, Or by his father there were none at all, For emulation who shall now be nearest Will touch us all too near, if God prevent not. O, full of danger is the Duke of Gloucester, And the Queen's sons and brothers haught and proud; And were they to be ruled, and not to rule, This sickly land might solace as before.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Come, come, we fear the worst; all will be well.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: When clouds are seen, wise men put on their cloaks; When great leaves fall, then winter is at hand; When the sun sets, who doth not look for night? Untimely storms make men expect a dearth. All may be well; but, if God sort it so, 'Tis more than we deserve or I expect.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Truly, the hearts of men are full of fear. You cannot reason almost with a man That looks not heavily and full of dread.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Before the days of change, still is it so. By a divine instinct men's minds mistrust Ensuing danger, as by proof we see The water swell before a boist'rous storm. But leave it all to God. Whither away?

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Marry, we were sent for to the Justices.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: And so was I. I'll bear you company.

scenes.location: London. A Room in the Palace

dialogues.speaker: Archbishop
dialogues.line: Last night, I hear, they lay at Stony Stratford, And at Northampton they do rest tonight. Tomorrow or next day they will be here.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: I long with all my heart to see the Prince. I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: But I hear no; they say my son of York Has almost overta'en him in his growth.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Ay, mother, but I would not have it so.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Why, my good cousin? It is good to grow.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper, My uncle Rivers talked how I did grow More than my brother. "Ay," quoth my uncle Gloucester, "Small herbs have grace; great weeds do grow apace." And since, methinks I would not grow so fast, Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold In him that did object the same to thee! He was the wretched'st thing when he was young, So long a-growing and so leisurely, That if his rule were true, he should be gracious.

dialogues.speaker: Archbishop
dialogues.line: And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
