dialogues.line: I hope he is, but yet let mothers doubt.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered, I could have given my uncle's Grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: How, my young York? I prithee let me hear it.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old. 'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth. Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: I prithee, pretty York, who told thee this?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Grandam, his nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: His nurse? Why she was dead ere thou wast born.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: If 'twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: A parlous boy! Go to, you are too shrewd.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Good madam, be not angry with the child.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Pitchers have ears.

dialogues.speaker: Archbishop
dialogues.line: Here comes a messenger. What news?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: How doth the Prince?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Well, madam, and in health.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: What is thy news?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret, And, with them Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Who hath committed them?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: The mighty Dukes, Gloucester and Buckingham.

dialogues.speaker: Archbishop
dialogues.line: For what offence?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed. Why or for what the nobles were committed Is all unknown to me, my gracious lord.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Ah me! I see the ruin of my house. The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind; Insulting tyranny begins to jut Upon the innocent and aweless throne. Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre; I see, as in a map, the end of all.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Accursed and unquiet wrangling days, How many of you have mine eyes beheld? My husband lost his life to get the crown, And often up and down my sons were tossed For me to joy and weep their gain and loss. And being seated, and domestic broils Clean over-blown, themselves, the conquerors Make war upon themselves, brother to brother, Blood to blood, self against self. O, preposterous And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen, Or let me die, to look on earth no more.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Come, come, my boy. We will to sanctuary. Madam, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Stay, I will go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: You have no cause.

dialogues.speaker: Archbishop
dialogues.line: My gracious lady, go, And thither bear your treasure and your goods. For my part, I'll resign unto your Grace The seal I keep; and so betide to me As well I tender you and all of yours. Go, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Welcome, sweet Prince, to London, to your chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign. The weary way hath made you melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: No, uncle, but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy. I want more uncles here to welcome me.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years Hath not yet dived into the world's deceit, Nor more can you distinguish of a man Than of his outward show, which, God He knows, Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart. Those uncles which you want were dangerous; Your Grace attended to their sugared words But looked not on the poison of their hearts. God keep you from them, and from such false friends!

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: God keep me from false friends, but they were none.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: My lord, the Mayor of London comes to greet you.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: God bless your Grace with health and happy days!

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: I thank you, good my lord, and thank you all. I thought my mother and my brother York Would long ere this have met us on the way. Fie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes not To tell us whether they will come or no!

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: And in good time, here comes the sweating lord.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: Welcome, my lord. What, will our mother come?

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: On what occasion God He knows, not I, The Queen your mother and your brother York Have taken sanctuary. The tender prince Would fain have come with me to meet your Grace, But by his mother was perforce withheld.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course Is this of hers? Lord cardinal, will your Grace Persuade the Queen to send the Duke of York Unto his princely brother presently? If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him, And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory Can from his mother win the Duke of York, Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurate To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid We should infringe the holy privilege Of blessed sanctuary! Not for all this land Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: You are too senseless-obstinate, my lord, Too ceremonious and traditional. Weigh it but with the grossness of this age, You break not sanctuary in seizing him. The benefit thereof is always granted To those whose dealings have deserved the place And those who have the wit to claim the place. This prince hath neither claimed it nor deserved it And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it. Then taking him from thence that is not there, You break no privilege nor charter there. Oft have I heard of sanctuary-men, But sanctuary children, never till now.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: My lord, you shall o'errule my mind for once. Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: I go, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may. Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come, Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Where it seems best unto your royal self. If I may counsel you, some day or two Your Highness shall repose you at the Tower, Then where you please and shall be thought most fit For your best health and recreation.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: I do not like the Tower, of any place. Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place, Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: Is it upon record, or else reported Successively from age to age, he built it?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Upon record, my gracious lord.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: But say, my lord, it were not registered, Methinks the truth should live from age to age, As 'twere retailed to all posterity, Even to the general all-ending day.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: So wise so young, they say, do never live long.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: What say you, uncle?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I say, without characters, fame lives long.  Thus, like the formal Vice, Iniquity, I moralize two meanings in one word.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: That Julius Caesar was a famous man. With what his valour did enrich his wit, His wit set down to make his valour live; Death makes no conquest of this conqueror, For now he lives in fame, though not in life. I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: What, my gracious lord?

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: An if I live until I be a man, I'll win our ancient right in France again, Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Short summers lightly have a forward spring.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Now, in good time here comes the Duke of York.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: Richard of York, how fares our loving brother?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Well, my dread lord-so must I call you now.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: Ay brother, to our grief, as it is yours. Too late he died that might have kept that title, Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: How fares our cousin, noble lord of York?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord, You said that idle weeds are fast in growth. The Prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: He hath, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: And therefore is he idle?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Then he is more beholding to you than I.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: He may command me as my sovereign, But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: My dagger, little cousin? With all my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: A beggar, brother?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give, And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: A greater gift? O, that's the sword to it.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Ay, gentle cousin, were it light enough.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: O, then I see you will part but with light gifts; In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: It is too heavy for your Grace to wear.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: How?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Little.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: My lord of York will still be cross in talk. Uncle, your Grace knows how to bear with him.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me. Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me. Because that I am little, like an ape, He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons! To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle, He prettily and aptly taunts himself. So cunning and so young is wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: My lord, wil't please you pass along? Myself and my good cousin Buckingham Will to your mother, to entreat of her To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: My Lord Protector needs will have it so.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Why, what should you fear?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost. My grandam told me he was murdered there.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: I fear no uncles dead.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Nor none that live, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Prince
dialogues.line: An if they live, I hope I need not fear. But come, my lord. With a heavy heart, Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Think you, my lord, this little prating York Was not incensed by his subtle mother To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: No doubt, no doubt. O, 'tis a parlous boy, Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable. He is all the mother's, from the top to toe.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Well, let them rest. Come hither, Catesby. Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend As closely to conceal what we impart. Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way. What think'st thou? Is it not an easy matter To make William Lord Hastings of our mind For the instalment of this noble Duke In the seat royal of this famous isle?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: He for his father's sake so loves the Prince That he will not be won to aught against him.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: What think'st thou then of Stanley? Will not he?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Well then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby, And, as it were far off, sound thou Lord Hastings How he doth stand affected to our purpose, And summon him tomorrow to the Tower To sit about the coronation. If thou dost find him tractable to us, Encourage him, and tell him all our reasons. If he be leaden, icy, cold, unwilling, Be thou so too, and so break off the talk, And give us notice of his inclination; For we tomorrow hold divided councils, Wherein thyself shalt highly be employed.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Commend me to Lord William. Tell him, Catesby, His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries Tomorrow are let blood at Pomfret Castle, And bid my lord, for joy of this good news, Give Mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Good Catesby, go effect this business soundly.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: My good lords both, with all the heed I can.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: You shall, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Now, my lord, what shall we do if we perceive Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Chop off his head, man; somewhat we will do. And look when I am king, claim thou of me The earldom of Hereford, and all the movables Whereof the King my brother was possessed.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I'll claim that promise at your Grace's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: And look to have it yielded with all kindness. Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards We may digest our complots in some form.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My lord, my lord!

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Who knocks?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: One from the Lord Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: What is't o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Upon the stroke of four.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Cannot my Lord Stanley sleep these tedious nights?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: So it appears by that I have to say. First, he commends him to your noble self.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: What then?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Then certifies your lordship that this night He dreamt the boar had razed off his helm. Besides, he says there are two councils kept, And that may be determined at the one Which may make you and him to rue at th' other. Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure, If you will presently take horse with him And with all speed post with him toward the north, To shun the danger that his soul divines.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Go, fellow, go. Return unto thy lord; Bid him not fear the separated council. His honour and myself are at the one, And at the other is my good friend Catesby, Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us Whereof I shall not have intelligence. Tell him his fears are shallow, without instance. And for his dreams, I wonder he's so simple To trust the mockery of unquiet slumbers. To fly the boar before the boar pursues Were to incense the boar to follow us, And make pursuit where he did mean no chase. Go, bid thy master rise and come to me, And we will both together to the Tower, Where he shall see the boar will use us kindly.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: I'll go, my lord, and tell him what you say.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: Many good morrows to my noble lord.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Good morrow, Catesby; you are early stirring. What news, what news in this our tott'ring state?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: It is a reeling world indeed, my lord, And I believe will never stand upright Till Richard wear the garland of the realm.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: How, wear the garland? Dost thou mean the crown?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders Before I'll see the crown so foul misplaced. But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: Ay, on my life, and hopes to find you forward Upon his party for the gain thereof; And thereupon he sends you this good news, That this same very day your enemies, The kindred of the Queen, must die at Pomfret.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news, Because they have been still my adversaries. But that I'll give my voice on Richard's side To bar my master's heirs in true descent, God knows I will not do it, to the death.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: God keep your lordship in that gracious mind.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence, That they which brought me in my master's hate, I live to look upon their tragedy. Well, Catesby, ere a fortnight make me older I'll send some packing that yet think not on't.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: 'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, When men are unprepared and look not for it.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: O monstrous, monstrous! And so falls it out With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey; and so 'twill do With some men else that think themselves as safe As thou and I, who, as thou know'st, are dear To princely Richard and to Buckingham.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: The Princes both make high account of you-  For they account his head upon the Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: I know they do, and I have well deserved it. Come on, come on. Where is your boar-spear, man? Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: My lord, good morrow; good morrow, Catesby. You may jest on, but, by the Holy Rood, I do not like these several councils, I.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours, And never in my days, I do protest, Was it so precious to me as 'tis now. Think you, but that I know our state secure, I would be so triumphant as I am?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London, Were jocund and supposed their states were sure, And they indeed had no cause to mistrust; But yet you see how soon the day o'ercast. This sudden stab of rancour I misdoubt; Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward. What, shall we toward the Tower? The day is spent.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Come, come. Have with you. Wot you what, my lord? Today the lords you talked of are beheaded.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: They, for their truth, might better wear their heads Than some that have accused them wear their hats. But come, my lord, let's away.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow. How now, sirrah? How goes the world with thee?

dialogues.speaker: Pursuivant
dialogues.line: The better that your lordship please to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: I tell thee, man, 'tis better with me now Than when thou met'st me last where now we meet. Then was I going prisoner to the Tower, By the suggestion of the Queen's allies. But now, I tell thee-keep it to thyself- This day those enemies are put to death, And I in better state than e'er I was.

dialogues.speaker: Pursuivant
dialogues.line: God hold it, to your honour's good content!

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Gramercy, fellow. There, drink that for me.

dialogues.speaker: Pursuivant
dialogues.line: I thank your honour.

dialogues.speaker: Priest
dialogues.line: Well met, my lord; I am glad to see your honour.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart. I am in your debt for your last exercise. Come the next sabbath, and I will content you.

dialogues.speaker: Priest
dialogues.line: I'll wait upon your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: What, talking with a priest, Lord Chamberlain? Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your honour hath no shriving work in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Good faith, and when I met this holy man, The men you talk of came into my mind. What, go you toward the Tower?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I do, my lord, but long I cannot stay there. I shall return before your lordship thence.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Nay, like enough, for I stay dinner there.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: And supper too, although thou knowest it not. Come, will you go?

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: I'll wait upon your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Sir Richard Ratcliffe, let me tell thee this: Today shalt thou behold a subject die For truth, for duty, and for loyalty.

dialogues.speaker: Grey
dialogues.line: God bless the Prince from all the pack of you! A knot you are of damned bloodsuckers.

dialogues.speaker: Vaughan
dialogues.line: You live that shall cry woe for this hereafter.

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: Dispatch. The limit of your lives is out.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody prison, Fatal and ominous to noble peers! Richard the Second here was hacked to death; And, for more slander to thy dismal seat, We give to thee our guiltless blood to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Grey
dialogues.line: Now Margaret's curse is fall'n upon our heads, When she exclaimed on Hastings, you, and I, For standing by when Richard stabbed her son.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Then cursed she Richard, then cursed she Buckingham, Then cursed she Hastings. O, remember, God, To hear her prayer for them, as now for us! And for my sister and her princely sons, Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood, Which, as thou know'st, unjustly must be spilt.

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: Make haste. The hour of death is expiate.

dialogues.speaker: Rivers
dialogues.line: Come, Grey, come, Vaughan, let us here embrace. Farewell, until we meet again in heaven.

scenes.location: London. A Room in the Tower

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Now, noble peers, the cause why we are met Is to determine of the coronation. In God's name speak. When is the royal day?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Is all things ready for that royal time?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: It is, and wants but nomination.

dialogues.speaker: Ely
dialogues.line: Tomorrow, then, I judge a happy day.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Who knows the Lord Protector's mind herein? Who is most inward with the noble Duke?

dialogues.speaker: Ely
dialogues.line: Your Grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: We know each other's faces; for our hearts, He knows no more of mine than I of yours, Or I of his, my lord, than you of mine. Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: I thank his Grace, I know he loves me well; But for his purpose in the coronation I have not sounded him, nor he delivered His gracious pleasure any way therein. But you, my honourable lords, may name the time, And in the Duke's behalf I'll give my voice, Which I presume he'll take in gentle part.

dialogues.speaker: Ely
dialogues.line: In happy time, here comes the Duke himself.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow. I have been long a sleeper; but I trust My absence doth neglect no great design Which by my presence might have been concluded.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Had you not come upon your cue, my lord, William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part- I mean your voice for crowning of the King.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder. His lordship knows me well and loves me well. My lord of Ely, when I was last in Holborn I saw good strawberries in your garden there; I do beseech you, send for some of them.

dialogues.speaker: Ely
dialogues.line: Marry, and will, my lord, with all my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you. Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business, And finds the testy gentleman so hot That he will lose his head ere give consent His master's child, as worshipfully he terms it, Shall lose the royalty of England's throne.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Withdraw yourself awhile. I'll go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: We have not yet set down this day of triumph. Tomorrow, in my judgement, is too sudden, For I myself am not so well provided As else I would be, were the day prolonged.

dialogues.speaker: Ely
dialogues.line: Where is my lord the Duke of Gloucester? I have sent for these strawberries.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: His Grace looks cheerfully and smooth this morning. There's some conceit or other likes him well When that he bids good morrow with such spirit. I think there's never a man in Christendom Can lesser hide his love or hate than he, For by his face straight shall you know his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: What of his heart perceive you in his face By any livelihood he showed today?

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Marry, that with no man here he is offended, For were he, he had shown it in his looks.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I pray you all, tell me what they deserve That do conspire my death with devilish plots Of damned witchcraft, and that have prevailed Upon my body with their hellish charms?

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: The tender love I bear your Grace, my lord, Makes me most forward in this princely presence To doom th' offenders, whosoe'er they be. I say, my lord, they have deserved death.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Then be your eyes the witness of their evil. Look how I am bewitched! Behold, mine arm Is like a blasted sapling withered up! And this is Edward's wife, that monstrous witch, Consorted with that harlot, strumpet Shore, That by their witchcraft thus have marked me.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: If they have done this deed, my noble lord-

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: If? Thou protector of this damned strumpet, Talk'st thou to me of "ifs"? Thou art a traitor. Off with his head! Now by Saint Paul I swear I will not dine until I see the same. Lovell and Ratcliffe, look that it be done. The rest that love me, rise and follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: Woe, woe, for England! Not a whit for me, For I, too fond, might have prevented this. Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm, And I did scorn it and disdain to fly. Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble, And started when he looked upon the Tower, As loath to bear me to the slaughter-house. O, now I need the priest that spake to me; I now repent I told the pursuivant, As too triumphing, how mine enemies Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered, And I myself secure in grace and favour. O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head.

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: Come, come, dispatch. The Duke would be at dinner: Make a short shrift. He longs to see your head.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: O momentary grace of mortal men, Which we more hunt for than the grace of God! Who builds his hope in air of your good looks Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast, Ready with every nod to tumble down Into the fatal bowels of the deep.

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: Come, come, dispatch. 'Tis bootless to exclaim.

dialogues.speaker: Hastings
dialogues.line: O bloody Richard! Miserable England, I prophesy the fearfull'st time to thee That ever wretched age hath looked upon. Come, lead me to the block. Bear him my head. They smile at me who shortly shall be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Come, cousin, canst thou quake and change thy colour, Murder thy breath in middle of a word, And then again begin, and stop again, As if thou were distraught and mad with terror?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian; Speak, and look back, and pry on every side, Tremble and start at wagging of a straw, Intending deep suspicion. Ghastly looks Are at my service, like enforced smiles, And both are ready in their offices, At anytime to grace my stratagems. But what, is Catesby gone?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: He is; and, see, he brings the Mayor along.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Lord Mayor-

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Look to the drawbridge there!

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Hark, a drum.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Catesby, o'erlook the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Lord Mayor, the reason we have sent-

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Look back! Defend thee, here are enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: God and our innocence defend and guard us! Enter Lovell and Ratcliffe with Hastings' head.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Be patient, they are friends, Ratcliffe and Lovell.

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor, The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: So dear I loved the man that I must weep. I took him for the plainest harmless creature That breathed upon the earth a Christian; Made him my book, wherein my soul recorded The history of all her secret thoughts. So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue That, his apparent open guilt omitted- I mean his conversation with Shore's wife- He lived from all attainder of suspects.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Well, well, he was the covert'st sheltered traitor That ever lived.- Would you imagine, or almost believe, Were't not that by great preservation We live to tell it, that the subtle traitor This day had plotted, in the council-house, To murder me and my good lord of Gloucester?

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: Had he done so?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: What, think you we are Turks or Infidels? Or that we would, against the form of law, Proceed thus rashly in the villain's death, But that the extreme peril of the case, The peace of England, and our persons' safety, Enforced us to this execution?

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: Now, fair befall you! He deserved his death, And your good Graces both have well proceeded, To warn false traitors from the like attempts.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I never looked for better at his hands After he once fell in with Mistress Shore. Yet had we not determined he should die Until your lordship came to see his end Which now the loving haste of these our friends, Something against our meanings, have prevented, Because, my lord, we would have had you heard The traitor speak, and timorously confess The manner and the purpose of his treasons, That you might well have signified the same Unto the citizens, who haply may Misconster us in him, and wail his death.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: But, my good lord, your Grace's word shall serve As well as I had seen and heard him speak; And do not doubt, right noble princes both, But I'll acquaint our duteous citizens With all your just proceedings in this case.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: And to that end we wished your lordship here, T' avoid the censures of the carping world.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: But since you come too late of our intent, Yet witness what you hear we did intend. And so, my good Lord Mayor, we bid farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Go, after, after, cousin Buckingham. The Mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post. There, at your meet'st advantage of the time, Infer the bastardy of Edward's children; Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen Only for saying he would make his son Heir to the Crown-meaning indeed his house, Which, by the sign thereof, was termed so. Moreover, urge his hateful luxury And bestial appetite in change of lust, Which stretched unto their servants, daughters, wives, Even where his raging eye or savage heart, Without control, lusted to make a prey. Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person: Tell them, when that my mother went with child Of that insatiate Edward, noble York My princely father then had wars in France, And, by true computation of the time, Found that the issue was not his begot; Which well appeared in his lineaments, Being nothing like the noble Duke, my father. Yet touch this sparingly, as 'twere far off; Because, my lord, you know my mother lives.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Doubt not, my lord, I'll play the orator As if the golden fee for which I plead Were for myself. And so, my lord, adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard's Castle, Where you shall find me well accompanied With reverend fathers and well-learned bishops.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I go; and towards three or four o'clock Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Go, Lovell, with all speed to Doctor Shaa.  Go thou to Friar Penker; bid them both Meet me within this hour at Baynard's Castle. Now will I go to take some privy order To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight, And to give order that no manner person Have any time recourse unto the Princes.

dialogues.speaker: Scrivener
dialogues.line: Here is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings, Which in a set hand fairly is engrossed, That it may be today read o'er in Paul's. And mark how well the sequel hangs together: Eleven hours I have spent to write it over, For yesternight by Catesby was it sent me; The precedent was full as long a-doing And yet within these five hours Hastings lived, Untainted, unexamined, free, at liberty. Here's a good world the while! Who is so gross That cannot see this palpable device? Yet who so bold but says he sees it not? Bad is the world, and all will come to naught When such ill dealing must be seen in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: How now, how now? What say the citizens?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord, The citizens are mum, say not a word.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Touched you the bastardy of Edward's children?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy, And his contract by deputy in France; Th' insatiate greediness of his desire, And his enforcement of the city wives; His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy, As being got, your father then in France, And his resemblance, being not like the Duke. Withal, I did infer your lineaments, Being the right idea of your father, Both in your form and nobleness of mind; Laid open all your victories in Scotland, Your discipline in war, wisdom in peace, Your bounty, virtue, fair humility; Indeed, left nothing fitting for your purpose Untouched or slightly handled in discourse. And when mine oratory drew toward end, I bid them that did love their country's good Cry "God save Richard, England's royal King!"

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: And did they so?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: No, so God help me, they spake not a word, But, like dumb statues or breathing stones, Stared each on other, and looked deadly pale. Which when I saw, I reprehended them, And asked the Mayor what meant this wilful silence. His answer was, the people were not used To be spoke to but by the Recorder. Then he was urged to tell my tale again: "Thus saith the Duke, thus hath the Duke inferred" But nothing spoke in warrant from himself. When he had done, some followers of mine own, At lower end of the hall, hurled up their caps, And some ten voices cried, "God save King Richard!" And thus I took the vantage of those few. "Thanks, gentle citizens and friends," quoth I; "This general applause and cheerful shout Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard." And even here brake off and came away.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: What, tongueless blocks were they! Would they not speak? Will not the Mayor then and his brethren, come?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: The mayor is here at hand. Intend some fear; Be not you spoke with but by mighty suit. And look you get a prayer-book in your hand, And stand between two churchmen, good my lord, For on that ground I'll make a holy descant. And be not easily won to our requests. Play the maid's part: still answer nay, and take it.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I go, and if you plead as well for them As I can say nay to thee for myself, No doubt we bring it to a happy issue.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Go, go, up to the leads, the Lord Mayor knocks. Welcome, my lord. I dance attendance here. I think the Duke will not be spoke withal. Now, Catesby, what says your lord to my request?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: He doth entreat your Grace, my noble lord, To visit him tomorrow or next day. He is within, with two right reverend fathers, Divinely bent to meditation; And in no worldly suits would he be moved To draw him from his holy exercise.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Return, good Catesby, to the gracious Duke; Tell him myself, the Mayor and aldermen, In deep designs, in matter of great moment, No less importing than our general good, Are come to have some conference with his Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: I'll signify so much unto him straight.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Ah ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward! He is not lolling on a lewd love-bed, But on his knees at meditation; Not dallying with a brace of courtesans, But meditating with two deep divines; Not sleeping, to engross his idle body, But praying, to enrich his watchful soul. Happy were England would this virtuous prince Take on his Grace the sovereignty thereof. But sure I fear we shall not win him to it.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: Marry, God defend his Grace should say us nay!

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I fear he will. Here Catesby comes again. Now, Catesby, what says his Grace?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: He wonders to what end you have assembled Such troops of citizens to come to him, His Grace not being warned thereof before. He fears, my lord, you mean no good to him.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Sorry I am my noble cousin should Suspect me that I mean no good to him. By heaven, we come to him in perfect love, And so once more return and tell his Grace. When holy and devout religious men Are at their beads, 'tis much to draw them thence, So sweet is zealous contemplation.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: See where his Grace stands 'tween two clergymen!

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Two props of virtue for a Christian prince, To stay him from the fall of vanity; And, see, a book of prayer in his hand, True ornaments to know a holy man. Famous Plantagenet, most gracious Prince, Lend favourable ear to our requests, And pardon us the interruption Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: My lord, there needs no such apology. I do beseech your Grace to pardon me, Who, earnest in the service of my God, Deferred the visitation of my friends. But, leaving this, what is your Grace's pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above, And all good men of this ungoverned isle.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I do suspect I have done some offence That seems disgracious in the city's eye, And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: You have, my lord. Would it might please your Grace, On our entreaties, to amend your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Know then, it is your fault that you resign The supreme seat, the throne majestical, The sceptered office of your ancestors, Your state of fortune, and your due of birth, The lineal glory of your royal house, To the corruption of a blemished stock; Whiles in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts, Which here we waken to our country's good, The noble isle doth want her proper limbs; Her face defaced with scars of infamy, Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants, And almost shouldered in the swallowing gulf Of dark forgetfulness and deep oblivion; Which to recure, we heartily solicit Your gracious self to take on you the charge And kingly government of this your land, Not as Protector, steward, substitute, Or lowly factor for another's gain, But as successively, from blood to blood, Your right of birth, your empery, your own. For this, consorted with the citizens, Your very worshipful and loving friends, And by their vehement instigation, In this just cause come I to move your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: I cannot tell if to depart in silence Or bitterly to speak in your reproof Best fitteth my degree or your condition. If not to answer, you might haply think Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty, Which fondly you would here impose on me; If to reprove you for this suit of yours, So seasoned with your faithful love to me, Then, on the other side, I checked my friends. Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first, And then, in speaking, not to incur the last, Definitively thus I answer you: Your love deserves my thanks, but my desert Unmeritable shuns your high request. First, if all obstacles were cut away, And that my path were even to the crown As the ripe revenue and due of birth, Yet so much is my poverty of spirit, So mighty and so many my defects, That I would rather hide me from my greatness, Being a bark to brook no mighty sea, Than in my greatness covet to be hid, And in the vapour of my glory smothered. But, God be thanked, there is no need of me, And much I need to help you, were there need. The royal tree hath left us royal fruit, Which, mellowed by the stealing hours of time, Will well become the seat of majesty, And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign. On him I lay that you would lay on me, The right and fortune of his happy stars, Which God defend that I should wring from him.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: My lord, this argues conscience in your Grace; But the respects thereof are nice and trivial, All circumstances well considered. You say that Edward is your brother's son; So say we too, but not by Edward's wife. For first was he contract to Lady Lucy Your mother lives a witness to his vow, And afterward by substitute betrothed To Bona, sister to the King of France. These both put off, a poor petitioner, A care-crazed mother to a many sons, A beauty-waning and distressed widow, Even in the afternoon of her best days, Made prize and purchase of his wanton eye, Seduced the pitch and height of his degree To base declension and loathed bigamy. By her, in his unlawful bed, he got This Edward, whom our manners call the Prince. More bitterly could I expostulate, Save that, for reverence to some alive, I give a sparing limit to my tongue. Then, good my lord, take to your royal self This proffered benefit of dignity, If not to bless us and the land withal, Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry From the corruption of abusing times Unto a lineal true-derived course.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: Do, good my lord. Your citizens entreat you.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffered love.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: O, make them joyful; grant their lawful suit.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Alas, why would you heap those cares on me? I am unfit for state and majesty. I do beseech you, take it not amiss; I cannot, nor I will not, yield to you.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: If you refuse it, as in love and zeal Loath to depose the child, your brother's son- As well we know your tenderness of heart And gentle, kind, effeminate remorse, Which we have noted in you to your kindred, And equally indeed to all estates- Yet know, whe'er you accept our suit or no, Your brother's son shall never reign our king, But we will plant some other in the throne, To the disgrace and downfall of your house. And in this resolution here we leave you. Come, citizens; zounds, I'll entreat no more.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: Call him again, sweet Prince; accept their suit. If you deny them, all the land will rue it.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Will you enforce me to a world of cares? Call them again. I am not made of stones, But penetrable to your kind entreaties, Albeit against my conscience and my soul. Cousin of Buckingham, and sage grave men, Since you will buckle Fortune on my back, To bear her burden, whe'er I will or no, I must have patience to endure the load. But if black scandal or foul-faced reproach Attend the sequel of your imposition, Your mere enforcement shall acquittance me From all the impure blots and stains thereof, For God doth know, and you may partly see, How far I am from the desire of this.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: God bless your Grace! We see it, and will say it.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Then I salute you with this royal title: Long live King Richard, England's worthy King!

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Tomorrow may it please you to be crowned?

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Even when you please, for you will have it so.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Tomorrow, then, we will attend your Grace; And so most joyfully we take our leave.

dialogues.speaker: Richard
dialogues.line: Come, let us to our holy work again. Farewell, my cousin, farewell, gentle friends.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Who meets us here? My niece Plantagenet Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester? Now, for my life, she's wandering to the Tower, On pure heart's love, to greet the tender Prince. Daughter, well met.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: God give your Graces both A happy and a joyful time of day.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: As much to you, good sister. Whither away?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: No farther than the Tower, and, as I guess, Upon the like devotion as yourselves, To gratulate the gentle Princes there.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Kind sister, thanks; we'll enter all together. And in good time, here the Lieutenant comes. Master Lieutenant, pray you, by your leave, How doth the Prince and my young son of York?

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: Right well, dear madam. By your patience, I may not suffer you to visit them. The King hath strictly charged the contrary.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: The King? Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: I mean the Lord Protector.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: The Lord protect him from that kingly title! Hath he set bounds between their love and me? I am their mother; who shall bar me from them?

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: I am their father's mother. I will see them.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother. Then bring me to their sights. I'll bear thy blame, And take thy office from thee, on my peril.

dialogues.speaker: Brakenbury
dialogues.line: No, madam, no. I may not leave it so. I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Let me but meet you, ladies, one hour hence, And I'll salute your Grace of York as mother And reverend looker-on of two fair queens.  Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster, There to be crowned Richard's royal queen.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Ah, cut my lace asunder That my pent heart may have some scope to beat, Or else I swoon with this dead-killing news!

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news!

dialogues.speaker: Dorset
dialogues.line: Be of good cheer, mother. How fares your Grace?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: O Dorset, speak not to me; get thee gone. Death and destruction dog thee at thy heels; Thy mother's name is ominous to children. If thou wilt outstrip death, go, cross the seas, And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell. Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughter-house, Lest thou increase the number of the dead, And make me die the thrall of Margaret's curse, Nor mother, wife, nor England's counted Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam. Take all the swift advantage of the hours; You shall have letters from me to my son In your behalf, to meet you on the way. Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: O ill-dispersing wind of misery! O my accursed womb, the bed of death! A cockatrice hast thou hatched to the world, Whose unavoided eye is murderous.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Come, madam, come. I in all haste was sent.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: And I with all unwillingness will go. O, would to God that the inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow Were red-hot steel, to sear me to the brains. Anointed let me be with deadly venom, And die ere men can say "God save the Queen."

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Go, go, poor soul; I envy not thy glory. To feed my humour, wish thyself no harm.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: No? Why? When he that is my husband now Came to me as I followed Henry's corse, When scarce the blood was well washed from his hands Which issued from my other angel husband, And that dear saint which then I weeping followed; O, when, I say, I looked on Richard's face, This was my wish: "Be thou," quoth I, "accursed For making me, so young, so old a widow; And when thou wedd'st, let sorrow haunt thy bed; And be thy wife, if any be so mad, More miserable by the life of thee Than thou hast made me by my dear lord's death." Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again, Within so small a time, my woman's heart Grossly grew captive to his honey words, And proved the subject of mine own soul's curse, Which hitherto hath held my eyes from rest; For never yet one hour in his bed Did I enjoy the golden dew of sleep, But with his timorous dreams was still awaked. Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick, And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Poor heart, adieu; I pity thy complaining.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: No more than with my soul I mourn for yours.

dialogues.speaker: Dorset
dialogues.line: Farewell, thou woeful welcomer of glory.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Adieu, poor soul, that tak'st thy leave of it.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Go thou to Richmond, and good fortune guide thee.  Go thou to Richard, and good angels tend thee.  Go thou to sanctuary, and good thoughts possess thee. I to my grave, where peace and rest lie with me. Eighty odd years of sorrow have I seen, And each hour's joy wracked with a week of teen.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower. Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes Whom envy hath immured within your walls- Rough cradle for such little pretty one, Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow For tender princes, use my babies well. So foolish sorrows bids your stones farewell.

scenes.location: London. A Room of State in the Palace

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Stand all apart. Cousin of Buckingham!

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: My gracious sovereign!

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Give me thy hand. Thus high, by thy advice And thy assistance is King Richard seated. But shall we wear these glories for a day, Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Still live they, and for ever let them last!

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Ah, Buckingham, now do I play the touch, To try if thou be current gold indeed. Young Edward lives; think now what I would speak.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Say on, my loving lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Why, Buckingham, I say I would be King.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Why, so you are, my thrice-renowned lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Ha! Am I King? 'Tis so-but Edward lives.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: True, noble Prince.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: O bitter consequence, That Edward still should live "true noble prince!" Cousin, thou wast not wont to be so dull. Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead, And I would have it suddenly performed. What sayst thou now? Speak suddenly, be brief.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Your Grace may do your pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Tut, tut, thou art all ice; thy kindness freezes. Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Give me some little breath, some pause, dear lord, Before I positively speak in this. I will resolve you herein presently.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: The King is angry. See, he gnaws his lip.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: I will converse with iron-witted fools And unrespective boys; none are for me That look into me with considerate eyes. High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect. Boy!

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Know'st thou not any whom corrupting gold Will tempt unto a close exploit of death?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: I know a discontented gentleman Whose humble means match not his haughty spirit. Gold were as good as twenty orators, And will, no doubt, tempt him to anything.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: What is his name?

dialogues.speaker: Page
dialogues.line: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: I partly know the man. Go, call him hither, boy.  The deep-revolving witty Buckingham No more shall be the neighbour to my counsels. Hath he so long held out with me, untired, And stops he now for breath? Well, be it so. How now, Lord Stanley, what's the news?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Know, my loving lord, The Marquess Dorset, as I hear, is fled To Richmond, in the parts where he abides.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Come hither, Catesby. Rumour it abroad That Anne my wife is very grievous sick; I will take order for her keeping close. Inquire me out some mean poor gentleman, Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter. The boy is foolish, and I fear not him. Look how thou dream'st! I say again, give out That Anne, my Queen, is sick and like to die. About it, for it stands me much upon To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me. I must be married to my brother's daughter, Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass. Murder her brothers, and then marry her- Uncertain way of gain! But I am in So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin. Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye. Is thy name Tyrrel?

dialogues.speaker: Tyrrel
dialogues.line: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Art thou indeed?

dialogues.speaker: Tyrrel
dialogues.line: Prove me, my gracious lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Dar'st thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?

dialogues.speaker: Tyrrel
dialogues.line: Please you. But I had rather kill two enemies.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Why then thou hast it; two deep enemies, Foes to my rest, and my sweet sleep's disturbers, Are they that I would have thee deal upon. Tyrell, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Tyrrel
dialogues.line: Let me have open means to come to them, And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel. Go, by this token. Rise, and lend thine ear.  There is no more but so. Say it is done, And I will love thee, and prefer thee for it.

dialogues.speaker: Tyrrel
dialogues.line: I will dispatch it straight.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: My lord, I have considered in my mind The late request that you did sound me in.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Well, let that rest. Dorset is fled to Richmond.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I hear the news, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Stanley, he is your wife's son. Well, look unto it.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: My lord, I claim the gift, my due by promise, For which your honour and your faith is pawned: Th' earldom of Hereford, and the movables Which you have promised I shall possess.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Stanley, look to your wife. If she convey Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: What says your Highness to my just request?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: I do remember me, Henry the Sixth Did prophesy that Richmond should be King, When Richmond was a little peevish boy. A king perhaps-

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: My lord-

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: How chance the prophet could not at that time Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: My lord, your promise for the earldom-

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Richmond! When last I was at Exeter, The Mayor in courtesy showed me the castle And called it Rougemount, at which name I started, Because a bard of Ireland told me once I should not live long after I saw Richmond.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: My lord-

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Ay, what's o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I am thus bold to put your Grace in mind Of what you promised me.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Well, but what's o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Upon the stroke of ten.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Well, let it strike.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Why let it strike?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Because that, like a jack, thou keep'st the stroke Betwixt thy begging and my meditation. I am not in the giving vein today.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Why then, resolve me whether you will or no.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Thou troublest me; I am not in the vein.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: And is it thus? Repays he my deep service With such contempt? Made I him King for this? O, let me think on Hastings, and be gone To Brecknock while my fearful head is on!

scenes.location: London. Another Room in the Palace

dialogues.speaker: Tyrrel
dialogues.line: The tyrannous and bloody act is done, The most arch deed of piteous massacre That ever yet this land was guilty of. Dighton and Forrest, who I did suborn To do this piece of ruthless butchery, Albeit they were fleshed villains, bloody dogs, Melted with tenderness and mild compassion, Wept like two children in their deaths' sad story. "O, thus," quoth Dighton, "lay the gentle babes;" "Thus, thus," quoth Forrest, "girdling one another Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, And in their summer beauty kissed each other. A book of prayers on their pillow lay, Which once," quoth Forrest, "almost changed my mind. But, O, the devil-" There the villain stopped; When Dighton thus told on: "We smothered The most replenished sweet work of nature That from the prime creation e'er she framed." Hence both are gone with conscience and remorse They could not speak; and so I left them both To bear this tidings to the bloody King. And here he comes. All health, my sovereign lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?

dialogues.speaker: Tyrrel
dialogues.line: If to have done the thing you gave in charge Beget your happiness, be happy then, For it is done.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: But didst thou see them dead?

dialogues.speaker: Tyrrel
dialogues.line: I did, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?

dialogues.speaker: Tyrrel
dialogues.line: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them, But where, to say the truth, I do not know.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon, at after-supper, When thou shalt tell the process of their death. Meantime, but think how I may do thee good, And be inheritor of thy desire. Farewell till then.

dialogues.speaker: Tyrrel
dialogues.line: I humbly take my leave.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: The son of Clarence have I pent up close; His daughter meanly have I matched in marriage; The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom, And Anne my wife hath bid the world good night. Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter, And by that knot looks proudly on the crown, To her go I, a jolly thriving wooer.

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: My lord!

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Good or bad news, that thou com'st in so bluntly?

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: Bad news, my lord. Morton is fled to Richmond, And Buckingham, backed with the hardy Welshmen, Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near Than Buckingham and his rash-levied strength. Come, I have learned that fearful commenting Is leaden servitor to dull delay; Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary; Then fiery expedition be my wing, Jove's Mercury, and herald for a king! Go, muster men. My counsel is my shield. We must be brief when traitors brave the field.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: So now prosperity begins to mellow, And drop into the rotten mouth of death. Here in these confines slily have I lurked To watch the waning of mine enemies. A dire induction am I witness to, And will to France, hoping the consequence Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical. Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret. Who comes here?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Ah, my poor Princes! Ah, my tender babes, My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets! If yet your gentle souls fly in the air And be not fixed in doom perpetual, Hover about me with your airy wings And hear your mother's lamentation.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Hover about her; say that right for right Hath dimmed your infant morn to aged night.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: So many miseries have crazed my voice That my woe-wearied tongue is still and mute. Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet; Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs, And throw them in the entrails of the wolf? When didst Thou sleep when such a deed was done?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Dead life, blind sight, poor mortal living ghost, Woe's scene, world's shame, grave's due by life usurped, Brief abstract and record of tedious days, Rest thy unrest on England's lawful earth,  Unlawfully made drunk with innocent blood.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Ah, that thou wouldst as soon afford a grave As thou canst yield a melancholy seat, Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.  Ah, who hath any cause to mourn but we?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: If ancient sorrow be most reverend, Give mine the benefit of seigniory, And let my griefs frown on the upper hand. If sorrow can admit society, Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine. I had an Edward, till a Richard killed him; I had a husband, till a Richard killed him. Thou hadst an Edward, till a Richard killed him; Thou hadst a Richard, till a Richard killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him; I had a Rutland too; thou holp'st to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard killed him. From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept A hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death: That dog, that had his teeth before his eyes, To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood; That excellent grand tyrant of the earth, That reigns in galled eyes of weeping souls; That foul defacer of God's handiwork Thy womb let loose to chase us to our graves. O upright, just, and true-disposing God, How do I thank thee that this carnal cur Preys on the issue of his mother's body, And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: O Harry's wife, triumph not in my woes! God witness with me, I have wept for thine.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Bear with me. I am hungry for revenge, And now I cloy me with beholding it. Thy Edward he is dead, that killed my Edward; The other Edward dead, to quit my Edward; Young York, he is but boot, because both they Matched not the high perfection of my loss. Thy Clarence he is dead that stabbed my Edward; And the beholders of this frantic play, Th' adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey, Untimely smothered in their dusky graves. Richard yet lives, hell's black intelligencer, Only reserved their factor to buy souls And send them thither. But at hand, at hand Ensues his piteous and unpitied end. Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray, To have him suddenly conveyed from hence. Cancel his bond of life, dear God, I pray, That I may live to say "The dog is dead."

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curse That bottled spider, that foul bunch-backed toad!

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: I called thee then, vain flourish of my fortune; I called thee then, poor shadow, painted queen, The presentation of but what I was, The flattering index of a direful pageant; One heaved a-high to be hurled down below, A mother only mocked with two fair babes; A dream of what thou wast; a garish flag, To be the aim of every dangerous shot; A sign of dignity, a breath, a bubble; A queen in jest, only to fill the scene. Where is thy husband now? Where be thy brothers? Where are thy two sons? Wherein dost thou joy? Who sues, and kneels, and says, "God save the Queen?" Where be the bending peers that flattered thee? Where be the thronging troops that followed thee? Decline all this, and see what now thou art: For happy wife, a most distressed widow; For joyful mother, one that wails the name; For one being sued to, one that humbly sues; For Queen, a very caitiff crowned with care; For she that scorned at me, now scorned of me; For she being feared of all, now fearing one; For she commanding all, obeyed of none. Thus hath the course of justice wheeled about And left thee but a very prey to time, Having no more but thought of what thou wast To torture thee the more, being what thou art. Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow? Now thy proud neck bears half my burdened yoke, From which even here I slip my weary head, And leave the burden of it all on thee. Farewell, York's wife, and Queen of sad mischance. These English woes shall make me smile in France.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: O thou well skilled in curses, stay awhile, And teach me how to curse mine enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Forbear to sleep the night, and fast the days; Compare dead happiness with living woe; Think that thy babes were sweeter than they were, And he that slew them fouler than he is. Bettering thy loss makes the bad-causer worse. Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: My words are dull. O, quicken them with thine!

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Thy woes will make them sharp and pierce like mine.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Why should calamity be full of words?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Windy attorneys to their clients' woes, Airy succeeders of intestate joys, Poor breathing orators of miseries, Let them have scope, though what they do impart Help nothing else, yet do they ease the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: If so, then be not tongue-tied. Go with me, And in the breath of bitter words let's smother My damned son, that thy two sweet sons smothered. The trumpet sounds. Be copious in exclaims.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Who intercepts me in my expedition?

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: O, she that might have intercepted thee, By strangling thee in her accursed womb, From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Hid'st thou that forehead with a golden crown Where should be branded, if that right were right, The slaughter of the Prince that owed that crown, And the dire death of my poor sons and brothers? Tell me, thou villain-slave, where are my children?

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence, And little Ned Plantagenet his son?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Where is the gentle Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Where is kind Hastings?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: A flourish, trumpets! Strike alarum, drums! Let not the heavens hear these tell-tale women Rail on the Lord's anointed. Strike, I say! Either be patient and entreat me fair, Or with the clamorous report of war Thus will I drown your exclamations.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Art thou my son?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Then patiently hear my impatience.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Madam, I have a touch of your condition, That cannot brook the accent of reproof.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: O, let me speak!

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Do then, but I'll not hear.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: I will be mild and gentle in my words.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: And brief, good mother, for I am in haste.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Art thou so hasty? I have stayed for thee, God knows, in torment and in agony.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: And came I not at last to comfort you?

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: No, by the Holy Rood, thou know'st it well Thou cam'st on earth to make the earth my hell. A grievous burden was thy birth to me; Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy; Thy school-days frightful, desp'rate, wild, and furious; Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous; Thy age confirmed, proud, subtle, sly, and bloody, More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred. What comfortable hour canst thou name That ever graced me with thy company?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Faith, none but Humphrey Hower, that called your Grace To breakfast once, forth of my company. If I be so disgracious in your eye, Let me march on and not offend you, madam. Strike up the drum.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: I prithee, hear me speak.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: You speak too bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Hear me a word, For I shall never speak to thee again.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: So.

dialogues.speaker: Duchess
dialogues.line: Either thou wilt die by God's just ordinance Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror, Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish And never more behold thy face again. Therefore take with thee my most grievous curse, Which in the day of battle tire thee more Than all the complete armour that thou wear'st. My prayers on the adverse party fight; And there the little souls of Edward's children Whisper the spirits of thine enemies And promise them success and victory. Bloody thou art; bloody will be thy end. Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse Abides in me, I say amen to her.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Stay, madam, I must talk a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: I have no more sons of the royal blood For thee to slaughter. For my daughters, Richard, They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens, And therefore level not to hit their lives.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: You have a daughter called Elizabeth, Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: And must she die for this? O, let her live, And I'll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty, Slander myself as false to Edward's bed, Throw over her the veil of infamy. So she may live unscarred of bleeding slaughter, I will confess she was not Edward's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Wrong not her birth; she is a royal princess.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: To save her life I'll say she is not so.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Her life is safest only in her birth.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: And only in that safety died her brothers.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: No, to their lives ill friends were contrary.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: True, when avoided grace makes destiny. My babes were destined to a fairer death, If grace had blessed thee with a fairer life.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Cousins, indeed, and by their uncle cozened Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life. Whose hand soever lanced their tender hearts, Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction. No doubt the murd'rous knife was dull and blunt Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart, To revel in the entrails of my lambs. But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame, My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys Till that my nails were anchored in thine eyes, And I, in such a desp'rate bay of death, Like a poor bark of sails and tackling reft, Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise And dangerous success of bloody wars, As I intend more good to you and yours Than ever you or yours by me were harmed!

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: What good is covered with the face of heaven, To be discovered, that can do me good?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Th' advancement of your children, gentle lady.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Unto the dignity and height of fortune, The high imperial type of this earth's glory.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Flatter my sorrows with report of it. Tell me what state, what dignity, what honour, Canst thou demise to any child of mine?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Even all I have-ay, and myself and all Will I withal endow a child of thine; So in the Lethe of thy angry soul Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs Which thou supposest I have done to thee.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Be brief, lest that the process of thy kindness Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Then know, that from my soul I love thy daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul. So from thy soul's love didst thou love her brothers, And from my heart's love I do thank thee for it.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning. I mean that with my soul I love thy daughter, And do intend to make her Queen of England.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
