dialogues.line: Well, then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Even he that makes her Queen. Who else should be?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: What, thou?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Even so. How think you of it?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: How canst thou woo her?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: That would I learn of you, As one being best acquainted with her humour.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: And wilt thou learn of me?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Madam, with all my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Send to her, by the man that slew her brothers, A pair of bleeding hearts; thereon engrave "Edward" and "York." Then haply will she weep. Therefore present to her-as sometimes Margaret Did to thy father, steeped in Rutland's blood- A handkerchief, which, say to her, did drain The purple sap from her sweet brothers' body, And bid her wipe her weeping eyes withal. If this inducement move her not to love, Send her a letter of thy noble deeds; Tell her thou mad'st away her uncle Clarence, Her uncle Rivers, ay, and for her sake Mad'st quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: You mock me, madam; this is not the way To win your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: There is no other way, Unless thou couldst put on some other shape, And not be Richard, that hath done all this.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Say that I did all this for love of her?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee, Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Look what is done cannot be now amended. Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes, Which after-hours gives leisure to repent. If I did take the kingdom from your sons, To make amends I'll give it to your daughter. If I have killed the issue of your womb, To quicken your increase I will beget Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter. A grandam's name is little less in love Than is the doting title of a mother; They are as children but one step below, Even of your mettle, of your very blood; Of all one pain, save for a night of groans Endured of her, for whom you bid like sorrow. Your children were vexation to your youth, But mine shall be a comfort to your age. The loss you have is but a son being King, And by that loss your daughter is made Queen. I cannot make you what amends I would; Therefore accept such kindness as I can. Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul Leads discontented steps in foreign soil, This fair alliance quickly shall call home To high promotions and great dignity. The King, that calls your beauteous daughter wife, Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother; Again shall you be mother to a king, And all the ruins of distressful times Repaired with double riches of content. What, we have many goodly days to see. The liquid drops of tears that you have shed Shall come again, transformed to orient pearl, Advantaging their loan with interest Of ten times double gain of happiness. Go then, my mother, to thy daughter go. Make bold her bashful years with your experience; Prepare her ears to hear a wooer's tale; Put in her tender heart th' aspiring flame Of golden sovereignty; acquaint the Princess With the sweet silent hours of marriage joys, And when this arm of mine hath chastised The petty rebel, dull-brained Buckingham, Bound with triumphant garlands will I come And lead thy daughter to a conqueror's bed; To whom I will retail my conquest won, And she shall be sole victoress, Caesar's Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: What were I best to say? Her father's brother Would be her lord? Or shall I say her uncle? Or he that slew her brothers and her uncles? Under what title shall I woo for thee, That God, the law, my honour, and her love Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Infer fair England's peace by this alliance.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Which she shall purchase with still-lasting war.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Tell her the King, that may command, entreats.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: That at her hands, which the King's King forbids.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Say she shall be a high and mighty queen.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: To vail the title, as her mother doth.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Say I will love her everlastingly.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: But how long shall that title "ever" last?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Sweetly in force unto her fair life's end.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: But how long fairly shall her sweet life last?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: As long as heaven and nature lengthens it.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: As long as hell and Richard likes of it.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Say I, her sovereign, am her subject low.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Then plainly to her tell my loving tale.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: O no, my reasons are too deep and dead- Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their graves.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Now, by my George, my Garter, and my crown-

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Profaned, dishonoured, and the third usurped.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: I swear-

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: By nothing, for this is no oath. Thy George, profaned, hath lost his lordly honour; Thy Garter, blemished, pawned his knightly virtue; Thy crown, usurped, disgraced his kingly glory. If something thou wouldst swear to be believed, Swear then by something that thou hast not wronged.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Now, by the world-

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: 'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: My father's death-

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Thy life hath that dishonoured.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Then, by myself-

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Thyself is self-misused.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Why, then, by God-

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: God's wrong is most of all. If thou didst fear to break an oath with Him, The unity the King my husband made Thou hadst not broken, nor my brothers died. If thou hadst feared to break an oath by Him, Th' imperial metal circling now thy head Had graced the tender temples of my child, And both the Princes had been breathing here, Which now, two tender bedfellows for dust, Thy broken faith hath made a prey for worms. What canst thou swear by now?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: The time to come.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: That thou hast wronged in the time o'erpast; For I myself have many tears to wash Hereafter time, for time past wronged by thee. The children live whose fathers thou hast slaughtered, Ungoverned youth, to wail it in their age; The parents live whose children thou hast butchered, Old barren plants, to wail it with their age. Swear not by time to come, for that thou hast Misused ere used, by times ill-used o'erpast.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: As I intend to prosper and repent, So thrive I in my dangerous affairs Of hostile arms! Myself myself confound! Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours! Day, yield me not thy light, nor, night, thy rest! Be opposite all planets of good luck To my proceeding if with dear heart's love, Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts, I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter. In her consists my happiness and thine; Without her follows to myself and thee, Herself, the land, and many a Christian soul, Death, desolation, ruin, and decay. It cannot be avoided but by this; It will not be avoided but by this. Therefore, dear mother-I must call you so- Be the attorney of my love to her; Plead what I will be, not what I have been; Not my deserts, but what I will deserve. Urge the necessity and state of times, And be not peevish found in great designs.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Ay, if the devil tempt you to do good.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Shall I forget myself to be myself?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Ay, if your self's remembrance wrong yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Yet thou didst kill my children.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: But in your daughter's womb I bury them, Where, in that nest of spicery, they will breed Selves of themselves, to your recomforture.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: And be a happy mother by the deed.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.line: I go. Write to me very shortly, And you shall understand from me her mind.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Bear her my true love's kiss; and so, farewell. Relenting fool, and shallow, changing woman! How now, what news?

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: Most mighty sovereign, on the western coast Rideth a puissant navy; to our shores Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends, Unarmed, and unresolved to beat them back. 'Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral; And there they hull, expecting but the aid Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Some light-foot friend post to the Duke of Norfolk. Ratcliffe, thyself, or Catesby. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: Here, my good lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Catesby, fly to the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: I will my lord, with all convenient haste.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Ratcliffe, come hither. Post to Salisbury. When thou com'st thither-  Dull, unmindful villain, Why stay'st thou here, and go'st not to the Duke?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: First, mighty liege, tell me your Highness' pleasure, What from your Grace I shall deliver to him.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: O, true, good Catesby. Bid him levy straight The greatest strength and power that he can make, And meet me suddenly at Salisbury.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: I go.

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: What, may it please you, shall I do at Salisbury?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: Your Highness told me I should post before.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: My mind is changed. Stanley, what news with you?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: None good, my liege, to please you with the hearing; Nor none so bad but well may be reported.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Hoyday, a riddle! Neither good nor bad. What need'st thou run so many miles about When thou mayst tell thy tale the nearest way? Once more, what news?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Richmond is on the seas.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: There let him sink, and be the seas on him! White-livered runagate, what doth he there?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: I know not, mighty sovereign, but by guess.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Well, as you guess?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton, He makes for England, here to claim the crown.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Is the chair empty? Is the sword unswayed? Is the King dead? The empire unpossessed? What heir of York is there alive but we? And who is England's King but great York's heir? Then tell me, what makes he upon the seas?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Unless for that, my liege, I cannot guess.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Unless for that he comes to be your liege, You cannot guess wherefore the Welshman comes. Thou wilt revolt and fly to him, I fear.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: No, my good lord; therefore mistrust me not.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Where is thy power, then, to beat him back? Where be thy tenants and thy followers? Are they not now upon the western shore, Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: No, my good lord, my friends are in the north.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Cold friends to me. What do they in the north, When they should serve their sovereign in the west?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: They have not been commanded, mighty King. Pleaseth your Majesty to give me leave, I'll muster up my friends, and meet your Grace Where and what time your Majesty shall please.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Ay, ay, thou wouldst be gone to join with Richmond. But I'll not trust thee.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Most mighty sovereign, You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful. I never was nor never will be false.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Go then, and muster men, but leave behind Your son George Stanley. Look your heart be firm, Or else his head's assurance is but frail.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: So deal with him as I prove true to you.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire, As I by friends am well advertised, Sir Edward Courtney, and the haughty prelate, Bishop of Exeter, his elder brother, With many more confederates, are in arms.

dialogues.speaker: Second Messenger
dialogues.line: In Kent, my liege, the Guilfords are in arms, And every hour more competitors Flock to the rebels, and their power grows strong.

dialogues.speaker: Third Messenger
dialogues.line: My lord, the army of great Buckingham-

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Out on you, owls! Nothing but songs of death? There, take thou that till thou bring better news.

dialogues.speaker: Third Messenger
dialogues.line: The news I have to tell your Majesty Is, that by sudden floods and fall of waters, Buckingham's army is dispersed and scattered, And he himself wandered away alone, No man knows whither.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: I cry thee mercy. There is my purse to cure that blow of thine. Hath any well-advised friend proclaimed Reward to him that brings the traitor in?

dialogues.speaker: Third Messenger
dialogues.line: Such proclamation hath been made, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Messenger
dialogues.line: Sir Thomas Lovell and Lord Marquess Dorset, 'Tis said, my liege, in Yorkshire are in arms. But this good comfort bring I to your Highness: The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest. Richmond, in Dorsetshire, sent out a boat Unto the shore, to ask those on the banks If they were his assistants, yea or no?- Who answered him they came from Buckingham Upon his party. He, mistrusting them, Hoised sail, and made his course again for Brittany.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: March on, march on, since we are up in arms, If not to fight with foreign enemies, Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: My liege, the Duke of Buckingham is taken. That is the best news. That the Earl of Richmond Is with a mighty power landed at Milford Is colder tidings, yet they must be told.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Away towards Salisbury! While we reason here A royal battle might be won and lost. Someone take order Buckingham be brought To Salisbury; the rest march on with me.

scenes.location: A Room in Lord Stanley's house

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Sir Christopher, tell Richmond this from me: That in the sty of the most deadly boar My son George Stanley is franked up in hold; If I revolt, off goes young George's head; The fear of that holds off my present aid. So get thee gone. Commend me to thy lord; Withal say that the Queen hath heartily consented He should espouse Elizabeth her daughter. But tell me, where is princely Richmond now?

dialogues.speaker: Christopher
dialogues.line: At Pembroke, or at Ha'rfordwest in Wales.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: What men of name resort to him?

dialogues.speaker: Christopher
dialogues.line: Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley, Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt, And Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant crew, And many other of great name and worth; And towards London do they bend their power, If by the way they be not fought withal.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Well, hie thee to thy lord; I kiss his hand. My letter will resolve him of my mind. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Will not King Richard let me speak with him?

dialogues.speaker: Sheriff
dialogues.line: No, my good lord; therefore be patient.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Hastings, and Edward's children, Grey, and Rivers, Holy King Henry, and thy fair son Edward, Vaughan, and all that have miscarried By underhand, corrupted foul injustice, If that your moody discontented souls Do through the clouds behold this present hour, Even for revenge mock my destruction. This is All-Souls' day, fellow, is it not?

dialogues.speaker: Sheriff
dialogues.line: It is.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Why, then All-Souls' day is my body's doomsday. This is the day which, in King Edward's time, I wished might fall on me when I was found False to his children and his wife's allies. This is the day wherein I wished to fall By the false faith of him whom most I trusted. This, this All-Souls' day to my fearful soul Is the determined respite of my wrongs. That high All-Seer which I dallied with Hath turned my feigned prayer on my head And given in earnest what I begged in jest. Thus doth He force the swords of wicked men To turn their own points in their masters' bosoms. Thus Margaret's curse falls heavy on my neck: "When he," quoth she, "shall split thy heart with sorrow, Remember Margaret was a prophetess." Come lead me, officers, to the block of shame; Wrong hath but wrong, and blame the due of blame.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: Fellows in arms, and my most loving friends, Bruised underneath the yoke of tyranny, Thus far into the bowels of the land Have we marched on without impediment; And here receive we from our father Stanley Lines of fair comfort and encouragement. The wretched, bloody, and usurping boar, That spoiled your summer fields and fruitful vines, Swills your warm blood like wash, and makes his trough In your embowelled bosoms-this foul swine Is now even in the centre of this isle, Near to the town of Leicester, as we learn. From Tamworth thither is but one day's march. In God's name, cheerly on, courageous friends, To reap the harvest of perpetual peace By this one bloody trial of sharp war.

dialogues.speaker: Oxford
dialogues.line: Every man's conscience is a thousand men, To fight against that guilty homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Herbert
dialogues.line: I doubt not but his friends will turn to us.

dialogues.speaker: Blunt
dialogues.line: He hath no friends but what are friends for fear, Which in his dearest need will fly from him.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: All for our vantage. Then in God's name, march. True hope is swift, and flies with swallow's wings; Kings it makes gods, and meaner creatures kings.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Here pitch our tent, even here in Bosworth field. My Lord of Surrey, why look you so sad?

dialogues.speaker: Surrey
dialogues.line: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: My lord of Norfolk.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Here, most gracious liege.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Norfolk, we must have knocks, ha, must we not?

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: We must both give and take, my loving lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Up with my tent! Here will I lie tonight. But where tomorrow? Well, all's one for that. Who hath descried the number of the traitors?

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Why, our battalia trebles that account. Besides, the King's name is a tower of strength Which they upon the adverse faction want. Up with the tent! Come, noble gentlemen, Let us survey the vantage of the ground. Call for some men of sound direction; Let's lack no discipline, make no delay, For, lords, tomorrow is a busy day. who pitch Richmond's tent.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: The weary sun hath made a golden set, And by the bright track of his fiery car Gives token of a goodly day tomorrow. Sir William Brandon, you shall bear my standard. Give me some ink and paper in my tent; I'll draw the form and model of our battle, Limit each leader to his several charge, And part in just proportion our small power. My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon, And you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me. The Earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment.- Good Captain Blunt, bear my goodnight to him, And by the second hour in the morning Desire the Earl to see me in my tent. Yet one thing more, good captain, do for me. Where is Lord Stanley quartered, do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Blunt
dialogues.line: Unless I have mista'en his colours much, Which well I am assured I have not done, His regiment lies half a mile at least South from the mighty power of the King.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: If without peril it be possible, Sweet Blunt, make some good means to speak with him, And give him from me this most needful note.

dialogues.speaker: Blunt
dialogues.line: Upon my life, my lord, I'll undertake it; And so God give you quiet rest tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: Good night, good Captain Blunt. Come, gentlemen, Let us consult upon tomorrow's business; Into my tent. The dew is raw and cold.  Soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: What is't o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: It's supper time, my lord. It's nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: I will not sup tonight. Give me some ink and paper. What, is my beaver easier than it was? And all my armour laid into my tent?

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: It is, my liege, and all things are in readiness.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge; Use careful watch; choose trusty sentinels.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: I go, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Stir with the lark tomorrow, gentle Norfolk.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: I warrant you, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Catesby!

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Send out a pursuivant-at-arms To Stanley's regiment. Bid him bring his power Before sunrising, lest his son George fall Into the blind cave of eternal night. Fill me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch. Saddle white Surrey for the field tomorrow. Look that my staves be sound, and not too heavy. Ratcliffe!

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Saw'st thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: Thomas the Earl of Surrey and himself, Much about cockshut time, from troop to troop Went through the army, cheering up the soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: So, I am satisfied. Give me a bowl of wine. I have not that alacrity of spirit Nor cheer of mind that I was wont to have. Set it down. Is ink and paper ready?

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: It is, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Bid my guard watch; leave me. Ratcliffe, about the mid of night come to my tent And help to arm me. Leave me, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: All comfort that the dark night can afford Be to thy person, noble father-in-law. Tell me, how fares our loving mother?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: I, by attorney, bless thee from thy mother, Who prays continually for Richmond's good. So much for that. The silent hours steal on, And flaky darkness breaks within the east. In brief, for so the season bids us be, Prepare thy battle early in the morning, And put thy fortune to the arbitrement Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war. I, as I may-that which I would I cannot- With best advantage will deceive the time, And aid thee in this doubtful shock of arms. But on thy side I may not be too forward, Lest, being seen, thy brother, tender George, Be executed in his father's sight. Farewell; the leisure and the fearful time Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love And ample interchange of sweet discourse, Which so-long-sundered friends should dwell upon. God give us leisure for these rites of love! Once more, adieu. Be valiant, and speed well.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: Good lords, conduct him to his regiment. I'll strive with troubled thoughts to take a nap, Lest leaden slumber peise me down tomorrow When I should mount with wings of victory. Once more, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.  O Thou, whose captain I account myself, Look on my forces with a gracious eye; Put in their hands Thy bruising irons of wrath, That they may crush down with a heavy fall Th' usurping helmets of our adversaries; Make us Thy ministers of chastisement, That we may praise Thee in the victory. To Thee I do commend my watchful soul Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes. Sleeping and waking, O, defend me still!

dialogues.speaker: Ghost Of Edward
dialogues.line: Let me sit heavy on thy soul tomorrow. Think how thou stabbed'st me in my prime of youth At Tewksbury; despair therefore, and die!  Be cheerful, Richmond, for the wronged souls Of butchered princes fight in thy behalf. King Henry's issue, Richmond, comforts thee.

dialogues.speaker: Ghost Of Henry
dialogues.line: When I was mortal, my anointed body By thee was punched full of deadly holes. Think on the Tower and me. Despair, and die; Harry the Sixth bids thee despair and die.  Virtuous and holy, be thou conqueror. Harry, that prophesied thou shouldst be King, Doth comfort thee in thy sleep. Live, and flourish!

dialogues.speaker: Ghost Of Clarence
dialogues.line: Let me sit heavy in thy soul tomorrow, I, that was washed to death with fulsome wine, Poor Clarence, by thy guile betrayed to death. Tomorrow in the battle think on me, And fall thy edgeless sword. Despair, and die!  Thou offspring of the house of Lancaster, The wronged heirs of York do pray for thee. Good angels guard thy battle; live, and flourish.

dialogues.speaker: Ghost Of Rivers
dialogues.line: Let me sit heavy in thy soul tomorrow, Rivers that died at Pomfret. Despair and die!

dialogues.speaker: Ghost Of Grey
dialogues.line: Think upon Grey, and let thy soul despair!

dialogues.speaker: Ghost Of Vaughan
dialogues.line: Think upon Vaughan, and with guilty fear Let fall thy lance. Despair and die!

dialogues.speaker: All Three
dialogues.line: Awake, and think our wrongs in Richard's bosom Will conquer him. Awake, and win the day.

dialogues.speaker: Ghost Of Hastings
dialogues.line: Bloody and guilty, guiltily awake, And in a bloody battle end thy days. Think on Lord Hastings. Despair and die!  Quiet untroubled soul, awake, awake. Arm, fight, and conquer for fair England's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Ghosts Of Princes
dialogues.line: Dream on thy cousins smothered in the Tower. Let us be lead within thy bosom, Richard, And weigh thee down to ruin, shame, and death; Thy nephews' souls bid thee despair and die.  Sleep, Richmond, sleep in peace, and wake in joy; Good angels guard thee from the boar's annoy. Live, and beget a happy race of kings; Edward's unhappy sons do bid thee flourish.

dialogues.speaker: Ghost Of Anne
dialogues.line: Richard, thy wife, that wretched Anne thy wife, That never slept a quiet hour with thee, Now fills thy sleep with perturbations. Tomorrow in the battle think on me, And fall thy edgeless sword. Despair and die!  Thou quiet soul, sleep thou a quiet sleep; Dream of success and happy victory. Thy adversary's wife doth pray for thee.

dialogues.speaker: Ghost Of Buckingham
dialogues.line: The first was I that helped thee to the crown; The last was I that felt thy tyranny. O, in the battle think on Buckingham, And die in terror of thy guiltiness. Dream on, dream on of bloody deeds and death. Fainting, despair; despairing, yield thy breath.  I died for hope ere I could lend thee aid, But cheer thy heart, and be thou not dismayed. God and good angels fight on Richmond's side; And Richard fall in height of all his pride.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Give me another horse! Bind up my wounds! Have mercy, Jesu!-Soft! I did but dream. O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me! The lights burn blue; it is now dead midnight. Cold fearful drops stand on my trembling flesh. What do I fear? Myself? There's none else by. Richard loves Richard, that is, I am I. Is there a murderer here? No. Yes, I am. Then fly. What, from myself? Great reason why, Lest I revenge. What, myself upon myself? Alack, I love myself. Wherefore? For any good That I myself have done unto myself? O, no, alas, I rather hate myself For hateful deeds committed by myself. I am a villain. Yet I lie, I am not. Fool, of thyself speak well. Fool, do not flatter. My conscience hath a thousand several tongues, And every tongue brings in a several tale, And every tale condemns me for a villain. Perjury, perjury, in the highest degree; Murder, stern murder, in the direst degree; All several sins, all used in each degree, Throng to the bar, crying all "Guilty, guilty!" I shall despair. There is no creature loves me, And if I die no soul will pity me. And wherefore should they, since that I myself Find in myself no pity to myself? Methought the souls of all that I had murdered Came to my tent, and everyone did threat Tomorrow's vengeance on the head of Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: My lord!

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Zounds! Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: Ratcliffe, my lord; 'tis I. The early village cock Hath twice done salutation to the morn; Your friends are up and buckle on their armour.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: O Ratcliffe, I have dreamed a fearful dream! What think'st thou, will our friends prove all true?

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: No doubt, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: O Ratcliffe, I fear, I fear!

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: Nay, good my lord, be not afraid of shadows.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: By the apostle Paul, shadows tonight Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers Armed in proof and led by shallow Richmond. 'Tis not yet near day. Come, go with me. Under our tents I'll play the eavesdropper, To see if any mean to shrink from me.

dialogues.speaker: Lords
dialogues.line: Good morrow, Richmond.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen, That you have ta'en a tardy sluggard here.

dialogues.speaker: Lords
dialogues.line: How have you slept, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: The sweetest sleep and fairest-boding dreams That ever entered in a drowsy head Have I since your departure had, my lords. Methought their souls whose bodies Richard murdered Came to my tent and cried on victory. I promise you, my heart is very jocund In the remembrance of so fair a dream. How far into the morning is it, lords?

dialogues.speaker: Lords
dialogues.line: Upon the stroke of four.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: Why, then 'tis time to arm and give direction. His oration to his soldiers. More than I have said, loving countrymen, The leisure and enforcement of the time Forbids to dwell upon. Yet remember this: God, and our good cause, fight upon our side; The prayers of holy saints and wronged souls, Like high-reared bulwarks, stand before our faces. Richard except, those whom we fight against Had rather have us win than him they follow. For what is he they follow? Truly, gentlemen, A bloody tyrant and a homicide; One raised in blood, and one in blood established; One that made means to come by what he hath, And slaughtered those that were the means to help him; A base foul stone, made precious by the foil Of England's chair, where he is falsely set; One that hath ever been God's enemy. Then, if you fight against God's enemy, God will, in justice, ward you as his soldiers; If you do sweat to put a tyrant down, You sleep in peace, the tyrant being slain; If you do fight against your country's foes, Your country's fat shall pay your pains the hire; If you do fight in safeguard of your wives, Your wives shall welcome home the conquerors; If you do free your children from the sword, Your children's children quits it in your age. Then, in the name of God and all these rights, Advance your standards, draw your willing swords. For me, the ransom of my bold attempt Shall be this cold corpse on the earth's cold face; But if I thrive, the gain of my attempt The least of you shall share his part thereof. God, and Saint George! Richmond and victory!

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: That he was never trained up in arms.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: He said the truth. And what said Surrey then?

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: He smiled, and said, "The better for our purpose."

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: He was in the right, and so indeed it is. Tell the clock there. Give me a calendar. Who saw the sun today?

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: Not I, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Then he disdains to shine, for by the book He should have braved the east an hour ago. A black day will it be to somebody. Ratcliffe!

dialogues.speaker: Ratcliffe
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: The sun will not be seen today! The sky doth frown and lour upon our army. I would these dewy tears were from the ground. Not shine today? Why, what is that to me More than to Richmond? For the selfsame heaven That frowns on me looks sadly upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Arm, arm, my lord. The foe vaunts in the field.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Come, bustle, bustle! Caparison my horse. Call up Lord Stanley; bid him bring his power. I will lead forth my soldiers to the plain, And thus my battle shall be ordered: My foreward shall be drawn out all in length, Consisting equally of horse and foot; Our archers shall be placed in the midst. John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey, Shall have the leading of this foot and horse. They thus directed, we will follow In the main battle, whose puissance on either side Shall be well winged with our chiefest horse. This, and Saint George to boot! What think'st thou, Norfolk?

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: A good direction, warlike sovereign. This found I on my tent this morning.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: "Jockey of Norfolk, be not too bold. For Dickon thy master is bought and sold." A thing devised by the enemy. Go, gentlemen, every man unto his charge. Let not our babbling dreams affright our souls; Conscience is but a word that cowards use, Devised at first to keep the strong in awe. Our strong arms be our conscience, swords our law. March on. Join bravely. Let us to it pell-mell, If not to heaven, then hand in hand to hell. His oration to his army. What shall I say more than I have inferred? Remember whom you are to cope withal, A sort of vagabonds, rascals, and runaways, A scum of Bretons and base lackey peasants, Whom their o'er-cloyed country vomits forth To desperate adventures and assured destruction. You sleeping safe, they bring to you unrest; You having lands, and blessed with beauteous wives, They would restrain the one, distain the other. And who doth lead them but a paltry fellow, Long kept in Brittany at our mother's cost? A milksop, one that never in his life Felt so much cold as over-shoes in snow? Let's whip these stragglers o'er the seas again, Lash hence these overweening rags of France, These famished beggars, weary of their lives, Who, but for dreaming on this fond exploit, For want of means, poor rats, had hanged themselves. If we be conquered, let men conquer us, And not these bastard Bretons, whom our fathers Have in their own land beaten, bobbed, and thumped, And in record left them the heirs of shame. Shall these enjoy our lands? Lie with our wives, Ravish our daughters? Hark, I hear their drum. Fight, gentlemen of England! Fight, bold yeomen! Draw, archers, draw your arrows to the head! Spur your proud horses hard, and ride in blood! Amaze the welkin with your broken staves! What says Lord Stanley? Will he bring his power?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My lord, he doth deny to come.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Off with his son George's head!

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: My lord, the enemy is past the marsh. After the battle let George Stanley die.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: A thousand hearts are great within my bosom. Advance our standards! Set upon our foes! Our ancient word of courage, fair Saint George, Inspire us with the spleen of fiery dragons! Upon them! Victory sits on our helms.

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: Rescue, my lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue! The King enacts more wonders than a man, Daring an opposite to every danger. His horse is slain, and all on foot he fights, Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death. Rescue, fair lord, or else the day is lost! Alarum. Enter King Richard.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: A horse! A horse! My kingdom for a horse!

dialogues.speaker: Catesby
dialogues.line: Withdraw, my lord; I'll help you to a horse.

dialogues.speaker: King Richard
dialogues.line: Slave, I have set my life upon a cast, And I will stand the hazard of the die. I think there be six Richmonds in the field; Five have I slain today instead of him. A horse! A horse! My kingdom for a horse!

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: God and your arms be praised, victorious friends! The day is ours, the bloody dog is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Courageous Richmond, well hast thou acquit thee! Lo, here, this long-usurped royalty From the dead temples of this bloody wretch Have I plucked off, to grace thy brows withal. Wear it, enjoy it, and make much of it.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: Great God of heaven, say Amen to all! But tell me, is young George Stanley living?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester town, Whither, if it please you, we may now withdraw us.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: What men of name are slain on either side?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: John, Duke of Norfolk, Walter, Lord Ferrers, Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir William Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Richmond
dialogues.line: Inter their bodies as becomes their births. Proclaim a pardon to the soldiers fled That in submission will return to us. And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament, We will unite the white rose and the red. Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction, That long have frowned upon their enmity. What traitor hears me and says not Amen? England hath long been mad, and scarred herself: The brother blindly shed the brother's blood; The father rashly slaughtered his own son; The son, compelled, been butcher to the sire. All this divided York and Lancaster, Divided in their dire division. O, now let Richmond and Elizabeth, The true succeeders of each royal house, By God's fair ordinance conjoin together, And let their heirs, God, if Thy will be so, Enrich the time to come with smoothed-faced peace, With smiling plenty, and fair prosperous days. Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord, That would reduce these bloody days again, And make poor England weep in streams of blood. Let them not live to taste this land's increase, That would with treason wound this fair land's peace. Now civil wounds are stopped, peace lives again. That she may long live here, God say Amen.
